reviewText:
This game is $35.
It adds HD graphics (it is pretty), controller support and windowed mode. That is all, at least that I've seen.
The DLC for this game is $25. It consists solely of costumes you will never use and are inferior to the base-game armors.

I've had the game lock up on me several times, unable to progress until I loaded a previous save from about an hour ago. You cannot save in the middle of missions. Good luck!

Fable: The Lost Chapters is available for $10 and includes all of the same content minus the DLCs and the aforementioned additions. Unless your hobbies include frivolous spending and frustration regarding games not working correctly, you should save your money.

reviewText: I was very excited about this game considering that Fable TLC is easily in my top 5 favorite games of all time. My expectations were simple: that this would be an upgrade to the beloved game I grew up playing. My mind was open when I first played Anniversary, knowing very well that the nastalgia from the first game would be influencing my feelings. Nevertheless, I would have expected my bias towards the series to lead towards a raving review. Instead I'm overwhelmingly compelled to advise other potential players to not waste their money on this lazy production.\n\nLaziness" on behalf of the developers is truly the best summary I can offer. The graphics have been updated  but that's where the careful effort ends. This game is loaded with bugs and glitches. I had to stop playing about maybe 1/8 of the way through because the pause menu got stuck. Let me repeat that: the pause menu got stuck. This is the only bug I'll take the time to mention because I think it's the most telling of how severely poor of a job the developers did porting the game. At some point
recommended: I stopped being able to access any of my clothing
hoursPlayed: inventory
voteText: or skills through the pause menu because it would continuously scroll through every tab and option. It was as if whatever key was supposed to scroll down was stuck (it obviously wasn't). To be unable to level up
helpfulPercent: use items or view quests in a game such as this simply means that it is unplayable.\n\nTake a moment to look up other glitches people have encountered. Even if they are not quite as critical as this they are indicative of the experience you'll have with this game. It falls short of so many basic
votesHelpful: fundamental expectations; it is a product without soul or passion.\n\nMy final
votesTotal: most disheartening complaint is probably trivial in comparison
votesFunny: but I have to mention it: you can't get drunk anymore. I don't think it's much to ask for -- it was a quirky feature that made frequenting the taverns fun. I can't even begin to tell you how many quests I would go on in TLC with my character knocking beers back one after another. When questioned about this absent feature in public forums the developers claimed that it was "a low priority". They've sacrificied gameplay
commentsCount: gutted stability and tossed away functionaility for better graphics in a new game engine.\n\nI remember playing the first game and having fantasies of how it could have been better. The game was great

column17: drilling down on the gameplay elements and turning it into a more immersive experience. The Anniversary release managed to step down that road then subsequently run in the opposite direction. It is a graphically-polished abomination."

reviewText:
*** I got this game and its dlc for free as a beta tester of this game ***

NOTE - this is a rereview for a game I failed to review the best I could the first time. Let me start this off by saying this: I was a late beta tester for this game and I am a Fable fan. I loved Fable (and similarly Fable: The Lost Chapters), thought Fable II was mostly great and hated Fable III... especially the dreadful PC port and the constant issues that followed it right until it got taken off of Steam. In retrospect, Fable: Anniversary was another Fable III -- mainly due to its disastrous launch. No mouse cursor on menus? Unbindable keys? These weren't big issues for me (mainly because I learned to put up with them) but I admittedly forgot to include them in my early review. On top of that, I seemed to have avoided most if not all of the technical issues that plagued the title at release date. The game, as far as I was concerned, was great.

Upon feedback I quickly found out this wasn't the case and included issues as well as their solutions in my review. I also became more active on the community hub so I could learn of new potential issues as well as help out others. The developers also quickly reacted based on feedback and within a few months had pumped out a considerable number of patches and hotfixes. TODAY the game has: full mouse and keyboard support, blurriness and depth-of-field fixed, stuttering resolved for the vast majority of users, numerous crashes sorted and various bugs addressed. These problems shouldn't have existed in the first place but nevertheless, I'm happy they got fixed honestly. So hopefully this rereview is more accurate this time around (I've included a Pros and Cons list now) and it doesn't look so nostalgic-y.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


A little bit about the game: Fable Anniversary is a remastering of the 2005 remake of the original 2004 title Fable". This 2005 remake is simply known as Fable: The Lost Chapters and was quite a sizeable overhaul in that it added new items
hoursPlayed: monsters
voteText: quests
helpfulPercent: locations
votesHelpful: abilities and more. In addition to minor tweaks
votesTotal: the remake also featured a slightly extended story as well as small subplots and relatively unimportant characters being made far more prominent in the game. Apart from this
votesFunny: Fable's still very much the same game at its core. It's an action/role-playing/semi open-world game and it has you playing as the Hero of Oakvale. I use "open-world" loosely as some areas are not unlocked until certain missions are completed (think Grand Theft Auto). Anyway
commentsCount: you start the game as a young boy who is to journey across the fictional land of Albion and make a name for himself.\n\nRight from the start the game's unique sense of humour
column16: somewhat dark story and moral alignment system are all presented and are on display. It's totally up to the player as to how you interact with everyone else and what kind of Albion you envision. Gameplay and controls are solid and very typical of a third-person game
column17: so they're not hard to get used to. Satisfying combat
column18: the variety of enemies and the 3 distinct fighting styles (melee
column19: ranged
column20: spells) all keep the player engaged. While the main story takes around 10-15 hours: character customization
column21: numerous sidequests and the various activities will massively inflate your playtime. There's also the memorable soundtrack to look forward to
column22: however
column23: the overall voice acting is something I struggle with -- its serviceable but it's not amazing either. All this being said
column24:
Fable's still a fun RPG and a game anyone can pick up and be entertained with.

PROS
+ runs on the Unreal Engine 3 and well optimized when compared to the original game (as of the latest patch)
+ true widescreen (unrestricted resolution with appropriate field-of-view; V-Sync caps the game at 60 FPS but disabling it will allow your PC to run the game at whatever FPS it can manage)
+ textures and “character updates” mostly look decent (although some will prefer the old look)
+ the new lighting system + particle effects
column25:
better facial animations and improved lip-sync are all great
+ audio quality has noticeably improved and surround sound is now supported
+ controllers are supposedly fully supported (I used a keyboard for all my playthroughs though)
+ new control schemes (one control scheme is inspired by Fable II and III which is neat)
+ new Heroic difficulty mode is fun and surprisingly challenging
+ most bugs
column27: balancing issues and major complaints from the original game have been addressed (e.g. you now age 50% slower and scar less from combat unlike the original game)\n+ Steamworks integration (cloud
column28:
achievements and workshop) and Steam trading cards
+ a few new outfits and weapons that weren't in the original game (these are free DLC from the Xbox 360 version)
+ free modding DLC (this didn't take off though and you only have clothes and animations to work with)

NEUTRAL
+/- severe lack of Steam workshop mods
+/- 2 pricey DLC packs that bundle together DLC from the Xbox 360 version (both are optional and give you additional weapons and outfits that weren't in the original game)

CONS
- the $35 price tag (for new players it's okay but I can understand why owners of the original game would feel it's a bit too much when the original game is great and still holds up well)
- the near-perfect UI from the original game has been swapped in exchange for one that feels more orientated for controller users (it’s clunky but still serviceable and feels less cluttered)
- the Hero of Oakvale’s face for all ages was changed (this visual update might frustrate some people as some of the faces in the original game looked better)
- some minor bugs still remain unfixed
- a few old animations that stand out nowadays
- no mouse sensitivity option (mouse-related options can be tweaked externally though)

It's always hard to recommend a remaster because of the new-game price tag but if you really enjoyed the original Fable or are new to Fable altogether: I can recommend this title. For those who own the game already... there may or may not be enough to justify purchasing this game. Some who liked the original game may even prefer Fable: The Lost Chapters over this and that's fine. Indeed
column29: Anniversary contains a lot of changes that can be noted as both good and bad but if you expected a remaster and just a remaster -- it should deliver for the most part. I think that's why it deserves a 8/10."

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, I played the original and really enjoyed it and I played the sequels and with each prgoressive game the quality got worse. Sure the visuals got better each time, but each time the humorous additives lessened until they were eliminated in Fable III. This return to the original is very disappointing. They upgraded the graphics yes, but that seems to be just about it. The controls are the same but can thankfully be retuned to their better counterparts from later games.

The animations are a HUGE disappointment. The models look a bit better but definitely nothing like what we saw in Fable III, the animations for them are not even remotely changed and this makes the new models pointless if they don't have updated animations as well. They still remain stiff and awkward and very simple.

The models themselves don't even do the original characters justice. Maze looks awful with that awful goatee that just sticks out like a sore thumb. Whisper's head is all wrong for the entire prologue looking like it should on a young adult whisper as opposed to a kid a little older than the player. The child character, oh man is that a monstrosity. It doesn't even remotely match or even harken to the old child hero. The new character models for villagers are at least decent. But overall the lack of attention or faithfulness to the original character designs does not bode well.

Thankfully the music is still quite good, but it is disappointing that nothing appears to have been remastered or redone as would be normal for a HD remake.

The cutscenes appear to not be changed at all, still using transparent renders from the original version.

Overall this HD" remake appears to be not even worth the effort Lionhead put in it
date: I had high hopes the new creative head would lead the company to better endeavours but clearly this is not the case. The HD remake hasn't done the game justice in my opinion and is definitely not worth 35 dollars. Maybe 15 if you stretch it. This isn't a HD re-release
recommended: it's a nostalgia trap.\n\n4/10 While the original game is still there
hoursPlayed: there's not been near enough done to improve on the old and just leaves the remake a flashy mess."

reviewText:
This is hardly a remaster. They put in new character models, and thats it. The animations are the same and the cutscenes were not redone and all have the resolution of a baked potato. Even the little gifs in the level up menu are the same. They show the old graphics and are compressed to all hell. On top of that, all the same bugs are present that were in the original. ALL OF THEM. Dialogue clips playing too late and getting cut off, bad camera that cuts off your face in cutscenes or shoots your neck, and for some reason the trader in the arena was closed (how?). There are also NEW bugs, like the animation for chests opening are apparently only 5 frames and look hella choppy. For god's sake the character models aren't even that good and all the hair and facial hair look plastered on. You can see that it starts as a texture and the hair model itself is just sort of hovering on top. At least in the original hair didn't look like it was glued on.

They also changed some of the game mechanics. Namely they changed it so that shops suck now. Its been a long time since I played the original, but I don't remember shops being this picky. A shop that specializes in gifts and crap that will buy rubies and diamonds, but not sapphires is ridiculous. Shops that will buy dark versions of armor but not bright or regular, shops only having 2 health potions in stock, shops that will buy my obsidian katana, but not my steel katana. What the hell kind of economy is this? I shouldn't have to go town to town just to find someone who wants to buy my ♥♥♥♥ing sapphires. They're sapphires.

This is a prime example of how bad a remaster can be. It's less mastered" than the original. They managed to lose some master while remastering."

reviewText:
Fable Anniversary delivers what it promised; A prettier version of the original game.
The game has aged well on its own, but the new graphics definitely make me personally want to play it more than the original. And that's honestly about it; it only ropes me in for the nostalgia.

This isn't a game for everyone, however, as it does run into some problems. I can't stand the new UI, which is clonky and harder to navigate than the original's, and the implementation of the DLC is pretty bland and honestly not worth considering. As others have no doubt already pointed out, the pricing is outrageous for a simple HD rerelease. For the full, and best experience of the Fable franchise, you're better off sticking to Fable: TLC which is only 10 dollars. Anniversary is about $35 with DLC being a total of $25. The DLC offers nothing new to the game except fancy accessories that are weaker than the Vanilla armors and weapons. $60 dollars for the full Anniversary" experience versus a $10 fee for the original vanilla experience. The difference in pricing is absurd

reviewText:
If you want Fable, go back to the original plus Lost Chapters.

I loved the original Fable, but this port is not worth the extra money. When first announced, I was excited because I thought they'd improve upon the original. Fix issues with the old one, gameplay or glitch wise, maybe add in a couple new quests, and fix the bad user interface and player menus.

Instead, it's really only a graphical difference. Worse yet, the graphics aren't really that much better. Sure, they smoothed things up and fixed up some lighting effects, but the models (especially the faces) are ugly as sin. I was hoping (more than anything else) they'd take a page from Fable 2 & 3, and give the option to buy a house without killing the occupants. Instead, it looks like that's still the plan. At least they looked at the menu options. Well, they looked but they did not fix. In fact, they made them worse. I bought this game for the PC, I WANT TO USE A KEYBOARD AND MOUSE. You cannot rebind keys. The default Keyboard/Mouse keys I cannot imagine are good for a right-handed player. For a left-handed player like myself, they're murder. The menu is horribly clunky. If I want an to equip a sword, for example. Imagine I've already navigated the maze of menu options to get there. Then, to actually equip the sword, you don't push enter. you push A. ON THE KEYBOARD. If you want to go back? B. The letter B. Not escape, that won't work.

Yes, I know controllers are available that work with my PC. I don't want them, I'm comfortable with my keyboard and mouse. As a big fan of Fable games (I own them all) this is insulting. The graphics are softer. The cutscenes still look like they're from the original (pixels EVERYWHERE). There's no customization to how I want to play a game that's all about customization. The User Interface is worse than before. There's a stupid book opening animation that has to play everytime you open the game or want to exit back to menu. This is a horrible addition to the Fable family. I'll probably play it again, I paid for it. Don't make the same mistake.

EDIT: Upon assistance from another player, he revealed that you actually need to be on your sepcific character before the option to change controls appears. While this provides immense relief, left-handed players may be distraught to discover you cannot rebind end, delete, pgdn or pgup, home or insert. Further, the numberpad keys cannot be assigned to the hotbar keys.

Still, I count this as a victory, and a lot of my stress about the game has been removed.

reviewText:
This game was a little rough at the start, I admit it.
Lionhead seems to be taking quick action with the PC Game and listening to the community.

Patches were deployed and the game is now PC friendly with mouse menu support and official workshop support.

The artwork has been entirely redone, but not to the point where it doesn't feel like Fable.
This game is for people who loved the Fable franchise and want to relive it in HD.

If you're expecting an entirely new game, you're going to be sorely disappointed. The remake is well done and will make Fable have longer replayability for that much longer.

reviewText:
As soon as you gain control of your character, you can feel this is an incredibly lazy port. The movement and camera are still very awkward, stubborn and juttery. Even though I'm using an analog stick, it feels like I'm playing a game entirely designed to work with a d-pad; I don't quite seem to have control, as though I'm telling my character where to go, and he's moving only in the vague direction. The character constantly gets caught on walls, boxes, anything he can find really.

All of this was in the original game, and it was forgiveable a decade ago, but now, they should really have done better. I know it sounds like I'm nitpicking, but poor movement and camera in an action RPG really mars an otherwise great game.

The graphics have been improved. Though they aren't fantastic, they are enough and make the game far more playable than the original, which has certainly not aged well in terms of looks.

Other than the graphics, all that seems to have changed is the UI. Parts are far better, other parts are the same if not worse. The d-pad menu in the bottom left is still atrocious to navigate, but the other menus are good now.

I have been recommending this game since the day it was released, and I will continue to, but I cannot recommend this port. The bare minimum effort has been put in, and it's clear within minutes that this is nothing but a cheap cash grab. I want more people to enjoy this amazing game, I really do. I just can't lie and say this is worth buying.

Fable deserves better than this.

reviewText:
Fable Anniversary is a fairly underwhelming remake of the original Fable.

The original Fable is a classic hack and slash/rpg. It's a simple game with a lot of humor and a nice focus on character customization. I greatly enjoyed playing through it as a variety of characters from an Archer who only used bows to a guy who just used his fists. It had a nice story and had lots of content with it's Lost Chapters release. To coincide with Fable's 10th anniversary the developers at Lionhead went about to remake the game. While I think their hearts were in the right place the execution is way off.

The things the remake does well can be seen in the screenshots. They ported the entire game to the Unreal 3 engine. They made the environments and lighting look absolutely steller. The way they made the lighting look on the player's armor looks impressive as hell but that's to be expected from such a modern engine.

That's... about all the improvements that are worth noting. The game plays identically to the original. While this isn't necessarily a bad thing it means negative aspects of the original game like the pathfinding and the friendly AI are still terrible. They also refused to add any new content the fans begged them to add like a female protagonist option. It is just a straight up port of the game to the Unreal 3 engine and it feels almost like a fanmade remake of the game.

This would be all well and good but a huge problem with this release of the game is how they decided to replace the character models. The characters in Fable Anniversary look like goblins. It clashes heavily with the exaggerated proportions the game has. The hair looks like plastic, and as a result half of the hairstyles from the original game look like absolute garbage. The lipsync is completely out of sync. Which would've been acceptable back in 2004 but is completely unprofessional for a game in 2015.

The absolute worst part of this release was the changed user interface. They replaced the very PC style user interface with this extremely clunky unintuative gamepad interface. It's hard to find what you want in the interface and you constantly select the incorrect parts of the menu. I HATE the interface in this release of the game. I don't understand how they could've dropped the ball so hard.

I can see the reasoning behind remaking Fable. But this really needed more care and attention put to it. It feels very paint by numbers like the developers really didn't know what people liked about the original game. Apart from the very welcome addition of xinput support, there is virtually no reason to buy this release over the original. Especially since the original is also on Steam, 30$ cheaper. I don't really know who to blame for this release of the game but considering how good Halo Anniversary was, I'm more inclined to blame Lionhead.

reviewText:
Do you like games where the UI is coded to disappear after a few seconds for no conceivable reason, and with no option to stop that from happening?

Do you like games that have a hotkey bar for quick item use but won't show it on the screen?

Do you like games that let you change your keybindings except for the ones displayed with a lock next to them because you aren't allowed to change them for some reason? Or how some keys can be assigned to multiple actions and others cannot for some reason?

Do you like games that give you the option to invert your look settings but don't give you look sensitivity options?

Do you like games that randomly decide to change what type of input controls you're using so suddenly your keyboard is useless?

Do you like games that are console ports of remakes of console ports of remakes that try to sell you on updated graphics?

Then you'll LOVE Fable Anniversary!

* * * June 14, 2015 Update * * *
It is stated that perhaps some or all of the issues laid out above may have been fixed in patches that were applied well after I posted this, so keep looking through the reviews as you may find more current information. Here's a picture of a sharkhorse http://i.picpar.com/Nyyb.jpg

reviewText:
...Before I shall say more, it is important for you to know that I never played Fable in the 1st place. I heard a lot of good reviews from my friends, so when they released Anniversary I knew that this game will be for me.

Despite the huge lot of negative reviews, I loved this game from start to finish. And yes, I have encountered a few techinical bugs on the way, but this was so unimportant in the long run, that I never seemed to care much.

Graphics were decent (and I was playing on low settings because my current setup is long outdated), the menus and loading screens were bright and colourful, and the game itself is pretty much the same Fable so many players loved, so what's the deal?

You may not agree with me, but I think it's a good idea to pick this edition during a sale or promotion for a lower price (price tag is kinda too high), better with all DLCs available (also discounted price) to play the game, get some nice achievements, Steam badge, cards and stuff like that. Not to mention a whole lot of fun which comes with the package.

...And that wraps it up, for me.

P.S.: sorry if this looks a bit messy. I hope you might find it useful anyway.

reviewText:
Please note: This review is based upon an initial release of the game, on September 12th, 2014. Some stuff might be fixed latter.

Cons:
1) Mouse can not be used in the main menu or any other menu in the game.
2) Keybindings for menus are awful, every time you want to upgrade a skill or change clothes you have to use Ins/Home and Del/End.
3) I'm not sure the save system is actually fixed like they promised (I reloaded a save in Hero Guild and I had to repeat all the quests that I already did once. Can't be 100% sure about this being a widespread problem as that was my only save/load situation for now). I'm never sure what will happen when I exit to desktop and return to game tomorrow.
4) While they changed visual style, textures look nothing like HD at all from close up (ie. Jack's face mask after Arena is a blur).
5) They said the character will age 50% slower than in TLC but mine was gray bearded after the first half an hour of the  game.
6) Everything looks a bit blurry and my eyes hurt.
7) Global map is almost unusable, just as before.

Pros:
1) You can get more than $5 back from GMG/Playfire rewards... if you play now and not in a year or so.
2) I had no encounters with game breaking bugs so far (progress: finished arena and met Jack), but be warned that some people from the forums did.

Summary: It's the same game as before, with a visual style changed... not sure it was for better. The only improvement over the TLC is being able to play in widescreen, but my 16:10 monitor has black bars on top and bottom of the screen, so they could not even make that right. I'm not saying the game is unplayable, it's OK and after some time you get used to it's quirks, but the reason I'm giving it thumbs down is because you can have the better version of this exact game for 3.49 eur during the sales, and they are asking over $27 for this thing where you can't even use a mouse to navigate the menus.

reviewText:
It's been just under 24 hours since Fable Anniversary has come to PC. I'd been waiting for this edition since it had been announced, and now I have my hands on it (so to speak). However, looking at the review section on Steam shows no shortage of angry gamers complaining about what they see as a shoddy console port. Almost never do initial reactions approach level-headed, so I want to take a step back and try to tell potential players exactly what they're getting.

Let me preface the rest of this review by saying that I don't strictly give this game a 'thumbs up' or 'thumbs down'. I'm not trying to be contrarian by labeling this review as positive, it's just what the system will let me do. We'll get back to this.

So, 'Fable Anniversary' is a remake-remaster hybrid of 2004's 'Fable', and includes the content from its expanded edition 'The Lost Chapters'. It was a very good game, and is now widely regarded as the best entry in the franchise (especially with regards to TLC). Unfortunately, the game suffered the fate of being way overhyped, by both creator and games media, and upon its release, fans were disappointed that some things were notably absent. The very first achievement you earn, “From The Smallest Acorn”, is a reference to a statement made by creator Peter Molyneux about just how deep the game world was supposed to be. Players were supposed to be able to knock an acorn off a tree, and it would grow into an oak. [NOTE: Molyneux DID say this, having discussed it in many interviews since, but I can't find the actual direct quote. If someone could source this I'd be grateful.] This was very obviously unfeasible given the time and technology, but it became a symbol of broken promises for people who bought the game with high expectations, and finished it feeling like something was missing. Again the acorn rears its head (or cupule if you're into trees, I guess), falling from the tree of the Lost Chapters, and foreshadows what is to come.

When I say this game “is a remake-remaster hybrid”, what I mean is that this is Fable 2014. This is Fable as you (probably) know it. Oakvale and the Guild and Bowerstone and all of those places are still here, and look mostly untouched, but more polished. If you played Fable back on the Xbox and remember being impressed by the graphics, this is probably how you remember it looking in your mind's eye. The boost in visuals comes from the game being rebuilt almost ground-up in Unreal Engine 3, which is what blurs the line between remake and remaster. Ten years of advancements in 3D technology will yield obvious results, but the game itself is mostly identical to the original Fable (more specifically the Lost Chapters, which was Fable but with a bunch of new quests and items). The acorn is planted.

This purist approach is a double-edged sword, though. One one hand, it means that fans of the original can be assured that the team isn't fixing what isn't broken, and new players can experience the same game without being taken aback by blurred textures and models that speak only by moving their jaw. These two groups can discuss the game with no real barrier between them. On the other hand, there really are some things about the game that could have been done away with. As an example, the game world is divided up into little sections. The Greatwood Forest is not one big forest you can wander through, but 8 smaller maps separated by loading screens. This was a necessity at the time because the Xbox couldn't have handled such a map, but 10 years later we have machines powerful enough to handle Skyrim and Just Cause. Not every area has a cullis gate, and it becomes tedious to run through these small areas and hit a loading screen between them just to get to some quest or secret. Also, the FMV's (pre-rendered videos) haven't been changed. At all. The opening cutscene shows what your character can look like in the future, and it's footage from the original release. I don't mean just the cutscenes, either. I mean every instance. When you go to upgrade your skills, you'll see a video on the right side of the screen showing what a particular upgrade does. These videos are straight from the original, not redone, meaning that you'll go from looking at the remastered visuals of Anniversary to seeing low-quality video of the original models lifting rocks and casting spells, which is very jarring. No sign of any oak tree.

Frustratingly, however, they didn't change these things while introducing new problems or altering things that shouldn't have been touched (or at least, should have been better thought-out). I'm not terribly near-sighted, but enough that I wear glasses for it. If someone wants to know what things look like to me without glasses, they just have to play this game. Distant trees and objects have this weird blur to them that can't be disabled in the game menu, instead relying on config file edits. The average user probably won't know how to do this, and the entirety of the video options menu really needs an overhaul. Speaking of which, the menus are horrendous, and they're what people have been pointing the finger at when they complain about Anniversary being a lazy port. These menus were very clearly designed with controllers in mind, and while I've been playing with one, I recognize that not everyone plays the same way. Rather than describing what's wrong with the keyboard and mouse controls, here's a video from TotalBiscuit going through the menu and showing how bad it is (youtu.be/3VP0aYKklsc). Maybe the acorn was a dud?

“But this is a PC version,” I hear some say, “surely the modders will fix these! Maybe the acorn will grow better if other people help water it!” Well, no. There are modding tools for the game, but they're strictly cosmetic. Head to the 'Modding DLC' store page, and you'll see that the tools are described as “only able to modify art and animation assets”. More than the menus, this game is screaming for fan-made content. Mods for Fable existed, but were very few, and even less worth installing. But in a game where the protagonist never says anything, players should be able to go nuts. They should be able to make new maps and characters and quests and add so much to the game, but instead we got dress-up. At least we can retexture the acorn to be gold.

I know I've spent most of this review criticizing the game, but that's because I was discussing the quality of the remaster and porting job rather than the game itself. The thing that made me choose to label this review positive over negative is this: Fable is a great game. It wasn't what everybody dreamed of, but I missed out on all the hype, and enjoyed the hell out of the final product. If you're the kind of person I'm trying to reach with this review, you want to know if this is worth buying. All I can say is that it depends. If you haven't played Fable before, or you have but just don't own it for PC, then I would recommend 'Anniversary', keeping in mind that the K/M interface is sub-par. If you already own the Lost Chapters, I can't justify recommending that you pay the current price for the same game, but with better graphics, controller support, a harder difficulty and achievements. But keep up with the news about this game. By the time this game is on sale, it will have been patched. Coupled with possible expansion of the modding tools, maybe this game will be what it should have been on release. Maybe, just maybe, if we wish for it with all our hearts, we'll see that oak grow.

reviewText:
I've decided to make a review for this because I've seen so many bad reviews, I feel nobody is outlining the amazing new features in this game. I haven't finished the story yet but I've played enough to know the ups and downs.

I've seen a few issues mentioned, I'd like to say that so far they seem based entirely on personal preference. Not that they're wrong but issues like crashing" I've not experienced any crashing what so ever and all the graphics are maxed out with TV being streamed on my second monitor. I would suggest that issue may be due to something else not that I'd know for sure but I've kept a solid frame rate without a single stutter.

There was a mention of issues with the controls. I have to agree slightly when I started playing I noticed they changed the controls by default to a new layout which is not so great for mages; To fix this just go to the controller settings and you can switch back to the original controller scheme which I prefer as you can access all spells rather than only having access to one spell at a time. The menu navigation isn't great but it's new
date: after a few hours I was used to it like any other game. The game clearly was only meant for controllers so it can't be faulted for not being perfect on keyboard/mouse.\n\nGraphics seem to be hated on? I love the redone graphics! It's certain changes that you really notice a difference

It's one thing that's kept the game fresh for me. Some of the faces are creepy in HD but really compare the 2. Also this isn't a next gen game you can only improve the graphics a certain amount.\n\nThis is a huge positive for me. The harder difficulty! reviewText: I do very few reviews-normally only on games that I feel strongly about. As far as Fable Anniversary goes, save your money. Especially if you already have the original version, if you don't just spend the 10 dollars and buy the original instead of throwing money away for this 'paint job' as most are calling it. The game runs smoothly with very few bugs that I've run across yet, got stuck in a wall once, rolled into a rock and got stuck, couple of game crashes- nothing major since the game auto-saves for you quite often. However, it is still the original game! Nothing has been added besides a few extra colors, sure it looks pretty that your shadow now follows the lighting properly but most of us don't really care about that beyond the first couple 'ooohs' and 'ahhhs'. The extra colors add a few more hues and textures but nothing mind blowing or game altering especially since most of the maps are darker toned anyway. All the in game movements of the characters, both your own and npc's, are blocky and out dated. The original game itself is still great and in all honesty with this play through I really haven't noticed anything that was worth the money I spent on the anniversary edition even at 50% off with the holiday sale. I have a feeling the developers were just looking for a way to make a quick buck with little work.\nNow that my ramble is done here's my point again: DO NOT BUY THIS VERSION OF THE GAME UNLESS IT DROPS BELOW  THE ORIGINALS PRICE!

reviewText:
Okay, this is a super sad review to write, because I was really enjoying this game.

The graphics are great, especially for a remaster! The sound is decent as well, though the soundtrack is mixed incredibly and is all-around fantastic!
Then why the negative review? Alright, well, it's because of the ending and the lackluster modding capabilities.

Without spoiling anything, the story ending is by far the most disappointing and lackluster I've ever played.
It seriously just drops everything, and there's nothing to do afterward. As someone who never played The Lost Chapters, this is heartbreaking. The journey up was pretty fun, but there was such a drop in content around the last quarter of the game. It became just story, with very few side quests. There aren't enough upgrades or unique loot drops to add any more replayability to the game. And the whole legacy of Whisper and Thunder just ends, regardless of the choices you make! What the hell, Lionhead?

The DLC in this game is $25 for skins and a few new weapons. There's nothing else.

The modding in this game is completely unpassable -- it requires 9 gigabytes of files just to run a mod! And there are only a small handful of them on the Workshop. Also, the way they made the modding tool only allows you to change very specific details, such as lighting in-game and skins. That's literally it -- and the tool is so user unfriendly that few people have even gotten around to making anything. This game has been out for a year, and there's only six or seven mods out for it. That's pathetic. And there's no one but the developers to blame on this.

Overall, if you get this game on sale for 75% off or more, then I'd go ahead and pick it up. I spent $12 when it was on sale, however, and felt cheated. I did get some good hours out of it, but the ending blew so hard that it made me feel like I hadn't really accomplished anything.

Not a bad game, but holy crap could they have done better!

reviewText: Well, I've been thinking about buying this game since quite some time now and I have to say that I don't regret it even one bit. I always loved Fable, it's probably the game I've played through the most (like 8 times now), it's one of my favorite games of all time and it was a part of my childhood. I played the original version on my old Xbox and I played The Lost Chapters on PC. So I think you realize by now how hyped I was for a remake. But despite all of that I always hesitated buying Anniversary, because of all the negative reviews about how buggy it is and such. Well, after my playthrough I can freely say that I didn't encounter a single bug and I didn't have any issues at all. That's why I could have an awesome experience with Fable yet again and I could re-live my childhood to a certain degree. My point is that you should buy this game, because it's hell of a lot of fun, it runs smoothly (even on not too good computers like mine) and because it looks amazing compared to the old game. If you're a Fable fan don't hesitate to pick it up and even if you're not a fan you should consider buying it, but you might want to wait for a sale because 32 euros kind of are a bit too much, eh?

reviewText:
Until all the keyboard and mouse controls are rebindable and there is a more functional mouse,  it's a waste of money.

Total Biscuit says it all.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3VP0aYKklsc&list=UUy1Ms_5qBTawC-k7PVjHXKQ

UPDATE - 1st posted on 09/28/'14 on raptr. I forgot about this one. Gomenasai
At launch Fable Anniversary had subpar graphics for a 2014 HD game and the genius who thought up the K&M controls should be fired.

It’s been patched (more than once) and now the graphics are what they should have been at launch and only now is it a better looking game than Fable:TLC.

When I tried, at launch, to remap Inventory to Tab and use the ‘E’ key for block, (a holdover from my TLC play throughs)  it wouldn’t allow remapping to the Tab key and all the remapped ‘E’ key did was sheath whatever weapon I had equipped.
The patches have fixed those keyboard issues, added Enter and Backspace as alternatives to the A & B keys and you can remap all keys.

Using the mouse in Inventory and Main Menu is still not possible.
I don’t know if Lionhead is responsible for that stroke of genius or if some asshat bean counter at Microsoft thought it would be a good way to increase controller sales.

From the size and positioning of the different HUD displays, it makes me think they were holdovers from a design for nearsighted console gamers.
The size and positioning of TLC’s HUD is still much better.

Overall it was a lazy, substandard port that still hasn’t been completely fixed.
I just finished a couple of play throughs (Chicken Chaser & Heroic Mode) and you get used to not having the mouse where you would normally use it. Not optimal but workable.

Heroic Mode was a nice addition but once you got good weapons (Skorm’s Bow and Cutlass Bluetane can still be gotten early in the game) and can buy (trading was completely nerfed. Even with max Guile you can't make any money trading an item back and forth with a trader.) or steal good armor, it’s still harder but not that much harder.

If you don’t own Fable Anniversary yet, play Fable:TLC and wait for a Steam sale to buy FA.

reviewText:
A lot of people are salty about this release, I get it. The Lost Chapters (which will be TLC from now on, go ahead and take a moment to load up Waterfalls on youtube) kept the faithful graphics that give it more of an edge, a grittier organic feel and the price difference is almost absurd.

But don't go chasing those waterfalls just yet. On a Chinese based website hosted on American based webspace ('g' two 'a' .com) this game is actually less than TLC, because of demand a lot of private sellers are able to sell this game for less than eight dollars, TLC is selling for just under nine.

So about my experience; I grew up watching my friends play this game when I was young. When it was originally released I was 13 and I didn't own an xbox. Many sleep-overs were spent watching my friend's epic adventures through Albion, at the time the game was pretty groundbreaking.

Now 12 years later I am finally experiencing the game from the pilot's seat, damn does it feel good.

The graphics are great for its age, the worst part of the remake being the camera which didnt quite survive the tinkering process; it is a little wobbly but I got used to it after an hour. Like I said I never really played the Fable games for myself in the past so I do not need the older graphics for nostalgia reasons but it would have been nice to have the choice to toggle between old and new.

So since the price between the games are so close on that Chinese site, I can only say that either one will satisfy you, just get the one that you feel makes the most sense to you and please stick to the rivers and the lakes that you're used to.

R.I.P. Lisa 'Left Eye' Lopes

reviewText: Oh boy. Where do i begin? Oh yes, this remaster sucks.\nFirst of all, the port is horribly done. The camera is locked on a slow as hell sensitivity, and it moves strangely. Mouse support in menus is non existent.  You have to use your keyboard purely when you're trying to navigate menus. And even that's poorly done. Sometimes in menus, the highlight for selecting will go into a random direction as if the arrow keys were sticking, making actually using these menus almost impossible to use. No matter what i do, it won't stop doing it. Some of the default keybinds are so random feeling. It's almost as if they attached printed image of a keyboard and threws darts to determine which key will do what. The combat lock-on is horribly done. You zoom in way to much, making your character take up half the screen. Fighting more than one enemy is extremely difficult. The dodge and block is the same key, which screws you over even more than most games that have multiple functions for 1 key. The delay in actually blocking has a massive delay, and not from doing other actions either. not matter what i do there's always a massive delay, making blocking almost impossible. Thankfully, dodging is actually useful, compared to blocking. The graphics have barely improved. It mostly looks like the textures were slapped onto the old fable 1 models. They look out of place and it makes the characters look hideous. Same for the lighting and environmental textures. Sure, you could say it's because it uses the same engine, but even then they were lazy in actually improving the graphics. The keyboard and mouse control scheme are horrid. Most of the time you have to go to the other side of the keyboard and back to actually do anything. I really wanted to like this game. I really did, but they were so lazy in actually making this as good as the original. If you really wanted to play this version, at least play with a controller. If even that doesn't work, get the Fable: the lost chapters. It's not only cheaper, but the combat mechanics are more enjoyable, and in general a better version.

reviewText:
This is Fable. You need to know that at the outset. If you didn't like Fable, TLC, 2, or 3, you're not gonna like this. If you had complaints, the odds are, they're still there. The keyboard/mouse control scheme isn't as good as it should be. DLC is a little wonky. You'll have to play around with your video settings to find what works for you.

But you know what? Every piece of that is worth it.

This is Fable. It was an incredible game ten years ago, and it's an incredible game now. Don't buy this because it's a brand-new AAA title that all your friends will be hardcore with, because that isn't Fable. Fable is funny. Fable is immersive. Fable is reminders about potions, food, and combat multipliers. Fable is mixing and matching pieces of armor to make your Hero look like you want them to. Fable is about single-player fun.

And this game delivers on that. If you liked Fable before, you'll like it now. And if you didn't? Then you probably won't enjoy this one. I love it. I think you could, too.

reviewText: Fable Anniversary is a colorful Action RPG set in the pomporous fantasy world of Albion. The player takes control of the hero and progresses from childhood to adulthood, making critical choices that affect your story. Quests are a dime a dozen, and although there might be more loading screens than most would expect from an open world game, it does nothing to contain the exploration of the wondorous realm. Albion is a fantasy like none other, with humor and intense action waiting behind every door. The combat is fluent and enjoyable; Not easy but not difficult to grasp. If you've played the other Fable games, it plays just the same. Yet the thing that stands out the most for me is the players interaction with the rest of the world. The expressions are fun and make for a very interesting mechanic, and the whole alignment system (as in good/evil) is one of my personal favorite mechanics of the game. Seeing the halo hover over my pomporous hero's head is very satisfying to say the least, and really gives weight to the choices presented to the player.\nAcclaimed as the best in the series, it's easy to see why this game receives so much love. Most of everyone is fully aware that this is a remake, and the original is available on steam. So is it worth $30? To me, very much so. It is a vast improvement from the original in all the best ways, without straying from the original greatness of the earlier edition. I know that some people prefer the original version, and there's nothing wrong with that. But this game isn't for those people, it's for new players to enjoy the game with a new and modern life in it, and for the true hardcore fans who are excited to revisit this beloved world in a new way. I understand that a lot of people are having problems with framerate and texture (which i haven't experienced my whole time in the beta), but the developers have been and will remain active! They have been great at addressing everyone's problems and fixing them, and i'm sure they will continue to do so. As for me, I'll continue to support Lionhead in hopes that this is the beginning of something great. Fingers crossed for Fable Legends and Fable 2 Anniversary!

reviewText:
Fable Anniversary still has control issues, though the patches have improved the game.

The menus are probably the worst.  The old menus, though unresponsive in their own right, are gone and replaced with something worse.  The mouse control functions like a d-pad, moving only one option at a time and requiring multiple clicks to change to a certain tab.  The menu keybinds (F4-F11) present in TLC are missing from Anniversary.  The hotbar keybinds are gone also.

The game is probably fine for casual play, but it's far too expensive to make up for this.  Fable: TLC will have much better menus, and look better to boot.

reviewText:
This is essentially a graphics update for the original Fable PC release from 10 years ago. If you've never played it before, it's still a great game (despite its issues) and if you can get this version at 75% off, it's worth it.

Otherwise, it's exactly the same game from 10 years ago if you've played it already, with all the same issues (and a few new bugs). Steam workshop support is worthless, the modding tools don't actually let you modify the game (only change textures and sounds) so don't expect to see any community expansion packs. At least cloud saves and trading cards are a nice addition.

Now that Microsoft has shut down Lionhead I don't expect anything to improve regarding this title, and I can't recommend it at the asking price. Get it on sale, or go buy the original version of the game.

reviewText:
Even though I'm used to the Keyboard and Mouse from playing Fable: The Lost Chapters a hundred times over, I went straight to the controller because I wanted to see how that felt and I was plesantly surprised. I haven't tried Key+Mouse, and looking at the reviews here, I don't think I will, but if you're willing to play with a controller, you shouldn't have any problems.

As for the game itself, I could tell you to save yourself some money and buy the original TLC, because it's the same game exactly, minus the graphic update which is nice, but not at all necessary to enjoy the awesome game it already was.

I'm still gonna recommend it for one little detail, and that's the Heroic Mode. Shops will have a limited supply of Health and Mana Potions, although you can still find both as loot for defeating enemies or from Traveling Merchants at a slightly marked up price. Vendors will now purchase whatever you sell at 50% of what it costs, which means no more making a fortune by Buying/Reselling Emeralds in Oakvale, no more Resurrection Phials, more expensive and less effective Physical Shield and Enflame and all enemies will be buffed and give you 40% less experience.

Heroic Mode feels a bit more like what the game should have been initially. Now, at the same time if you're like me, and you like to powergame, it'll just make it a bit grindier  but overall more challenging, which is nice.

reviewText:
Fable is a great game. The combat is simple and fun, with a good variety of weapons and spells that you are fully encouraged to explore. There is a lot of great British humor, and a lot of charming character is put into the environment and the people and things that inhabit it. There is a cool simple morality system, wherein the world and the people in it react appropriately to your deeds and if you are a good guy/bad guy. There are also a lot of little extra role playing touches, like the ability to get married and have kids, that ultimately don't change the game much but it is really nice that they are there. So yeah, if you like RPGs, you should totally dig up a copy of Fable for Xbox (or maybe the GFWL version if you can find it) for a very fun and light Zelda-esq adventure experience.

Unfortunately, this port does not do Fable justice. This port feels like a step backwards from the original Xbox version in almost every way.

The first glaring issue is the menus. The menus are incredibly clunky and hard to navigate. Bafflingly, some of the menus seem to allow mouse navigation, and then other menus force you to use your keyboard to navigate them. As far as I can tell, there is no rhyme or reason as to which menus are mouse navigable and which are not. It is not uncommon to start off browsing through the first tier of a menu with your mouse, then when you get to the next tier you suddenly can't click anything and have to use incredibly clunky keyboard commands to continue through.

The next issue I have with this mess would be the controls. To put it simply, this game controls like absolute poop if you use a keyboard and mouse. The mouse feels jittery and not accurate. As for the keyboard stuff well, any time a game makes you use the Backspace" key as a common control
date: you know you are in trouble.\n\nGraphically
recommended: this game is a mixed bag. On the one hand
hoursPlayed: some of the lighting techniques seem to have been modernized
voteText: and there seems to have been some modeling work. On the other hand
helpfulPercent: the new higher poly models that they added to the game just don't look very good. This issue may be entirely subjective
votesHelpful: but the new models just kind of look weird and lack the same interesting character that the original models had.\n\nAs for the kind of graphical options tweaks
votesTotal: this game is your typical lazy PC port in that it offers you very little in terms of video options.\n\nTo sum this up
votesFunny: this just feels like a cheap
commentsCount: not particularly good port. Combine that with the ludicrous price tag
column16: and I'd say that you should never touch this game with a ten foot pole. This is a shame
column17: because the core game of Fable is really
column18: really good. Fable deserves better than this. Moreover
column19: YOU deserve better than this. Don't buy this game."

reviewText:
Good game, decent texture upgrades.
But not enough to justify the price they are asking.

The improvements made to this game are the equivalent of an Medium HD Texture pack. (Low, Medium, High, Ultra)

In games like Skyrim, you can get this kind of upgrade for free from the community.

The biggest dissappointment of all?
All the animations are exactly the same.
Which tells me... the only areas they even attempted to polish were some meshes and textures.

I'm sorry, but for the price you are asking.
I would at least expect you to polish up the animations as well.

Maybe even improve upon the way archery works.
Because lets face it, manually aiming, zooming and shooting a bow could use ALOT of improvement.

In fact, the entire targetting system could have been improved.
The way targeting works in anniverasy seems worse than the original.
Something simple like.. while locked on, press d-pad left or right to switch targets...

Instead it is...
Slightly let off left trigger then re-press it again and hope it picks the target you wanted.

When you consider the amount of effort that went into this Anniversary Edition and it's improvments...

I would wait till it's 75% off.

reviewText:
After several updates I am happy to say the game has been made a lot better.  Mouse support has been added to the menus and the game has become a lot more polished.  So now I'll break it down into the pros and cons like I should have done in my original revirew.

Pros
+ Runs fairly well which is great considering this is an Xbox to PC port.
+ Graphical Fidelity is actually not that bad and looks a hell of a lot better than the original did
+ Most keys can be rebound if you so desire
+ Full 1080p Support

Cons
+ Lack of mods in the workshop
+ Weapon balncing is a bit off.  You get really strong weapons early game but later near the end game the weapons you find seem a bit weak.
+ Menu navigation is still a bit tedious.

Can I recommend this over the original Lost Chapters? No if you've already got it, yes if you haven't played TLC before.

Since the updates the game has become a lot more PC friendly which is a good, and isn't actually a bad game in its own right.

reviewText:
Alright, so let me say I may be a little biased, because Lionhead has bribed me with all the sun shaft effects.

Ok, so basically, this game is a graphical enhancement to Fable: The Lost Chapters. And for all these other people reviewing, they are downvoting because they expected even more stuff to be in the game, which I find quite stupid because the whole point of re-making games like this is so that people who haven't played it yet can experiance it where it looks even better, or for nastolgia's sake.

Alright, so here is the basic run down of good and bad:

GOOD:

- All the models, animations (Some of these are still the origional), textures, and light FX have been redone
- The game looks really pretty on the max settings, and some of the movement is even smoother than before
- Combat is still massively fun
- Stays true to the origional's everything, but they did add some outfits though
- The game supports modding, and even gives a free DLC to get the SDK
- They are releasing some new content packs to add more to the game

BAD:

- When you save, it only saves from your last checkpoint, sometimes you have to redo a thing or two (not very game breaking though)
- The eye's pupils are too big on some characters, making the game look a little awkward
- Textures can sometimes be a little lower resolution than would be expected
- Texture poping sometimes happens (Unreal Engine's fault, not the devs)

Overall, I would have to recommend this game. All the people asking for this need to stop complaining about the little things, all of them will either be fixed by lionhead or by modders. I don't know about you guys, but I am having a great time.

So overall, about an 8.7/10

EDIT; They added keyboard and mouse support in menus. It could have been better, but its on par so I dont really view it as a bad thing

reviewText:
Fable Anniversary is a prime example of how NOT to handle a re-mastered game.

I love the Fable series to death. TLC remains my favorite RPG to date. Some compatibility issues prevent me from playing the original Fable TLC on my PC, so I purchased FA in order to still play it. While the general gameplay is exactly the same, they destroyed everything else.

First of all, this was supposed to IMPROVE the graphics: not just add more polygons and change the lighting. The textures are horrible, the models are even worse, and the lighting makes me want to carve out my own eyes. Everything is incredibly dull and grey - the opposite of the original, bright and colorful Fable.

What's worse than the graphics is the menu system. At first there was no mouse support for any of the menus. NO MOUSE SUPPORT ON A PC GAME. Okay, it's not THAT big of a deal, right? We can still use the arrow keys and enter"
date: right? Nope. You use Insert and Delete to navigate. Explain this sh*t to me.\n\nThey have since updated the game
recommended: and we can now use a mouse in the menus. However
hoursPlayed: they are still the clunkiest
voteText: unnecessarily difficult menus I have ever used. This is the worst part of the game being ported from Xbox.\n\nAll in all

reviewText:
I enjoyed Fable: Lost Chapters when it was first released years ago; and it did not age well.

This update to the aging game was a welcome sight, so I purchased the game when it was on a flash sale, for a third of its normal price.

The graphical update is fairly well done, and keeps to the cartoonish look of the original, it looks like they tried to fix some of the issues with the original game as well.

That's where the good parts of the game come to an end though.

It's a good thing that you can now save anywhere, as you'll see your desktop more often than you'd like. The game crashes during entirely mundane activities (walking, etc.) for no apparent reason.

The controller support was a nice touch, and they tried to make it more user friendly (failing mind you, as it feels as though the 'improved' controls are somehow worse than the original). However the game is sluggish and unresponsive. I find myself being struck where I wouldn't be, had I been playing the original.

Taking everything in consideration, I can't recommend this game at it's normal price. Pick it up on the cheap, during a flash sale, or holiday sale; otherwise, look for something more worthwhile.

reviewText:
Quick fixes in this review so read carefully if you want a great play experience.

Alright, so I've read all the other reviews and I agree with most of them; however, there are some easy fixes to most of the problems.  Yes, there is a stuttering issue that is incredibly annoying.  It is rough being able to run Crysis 3 on ultra and not being able to run Fable on anything.  To fix this - cntrl alt delete and set fable's affinity to cpu 0 only.  The game was originally designed during a time when almost everything only ever used 1 core.  This does fix the issue and it runs perfect after.  I have a gtx 780...it is not nvidia that is the issue.  Nvidia runs fine with this program.  The FPS problem people are complaining about are because they have both integrated and dedicated graphics.  If you have an AMD APU or 4th gen intel the integrated graphics should be fine and you won't even notice (I have a 4th gen intel and just leave it running off that).  If you are still having issues though,  just go to Nvidia control panel and select the Manage 3D Settings tab. After that “select Program Settings” and find Fable Anniversary and switch the game to your Nvidia graphics card". quoted from segmentnext.com because I'm lazy.

The game is best ran with a controller.  I have a cheap logitech i use for my emulated stuff and it works fine.  If you are going to use the keyboard
date: it isn't too bad but it isn't anything like the original.  I think people don't like change and just love complaining.  It is what it is.  Another complaint I heard plenty of was the lack of "video" options.  There are some assumtions made by the developers
recommended: if you have a computer today it will be able to play everything from 2009 on max.  They have some distance and shadow options for slower computers.  Fine assumption for a port

reviewText: This game is quite dissappointing.\nFable is a classic RPG probably every gamer is familiar with, and it deserves a proper reconstruction, but this is not it. Fable was ahead of its time and as you might expect lacks a number of modern design principles we all know today, but which did not exist back then. There have been a few new features added (mostly just some spells and new armors/weapons), as well as some things taken away, including some plot elements. Beside that, this game is the old Fable + hi comp art + poorly executed KB/mouse control. They haven't done any bug/flaw fixing so your imerssion is just as regularly interrupted by mistakes in the game as it was in Fable for XBOX. The control and combat system is also quite awful. However, they've made the combat easier than ever because the enemies seem tremendously easier to kill and deal far less damage to the player's character. It is pretty much impossible to die, yet they throw extra lives at you like they are going out of style. Frankly they've made what was a fairly entertaining combat system into something unenjoyable and unchallenging. Special points like renown and alignment accumulate much faster than they used to, so they max out shortly after starting the game. So, if you're really not interested in a good, fun game to get into, and you just want to relax and goof off for a while with something graphically-rich, this may be a good option for you. Otherwise, go play the original Fable on XBOX, it is far more satisfying.

reviewText:
I loved Fable TLC and have played it at least 4 times over the years.  When I heard about Fable Anniversary and saw some of the preview pics I made a point to pre-order.  That was a mistake.

The graphics are largely better than Fable TLC, but still underwhelming.  On close up the hero's hair looks bad, and Whisper's looks even worse.  There's odd lighting around the hair and face of the models.  The hero's eyes look dead - totally a 2 dimensional surface.  You can see this in TotalBiscut's review at about the 11:25 mark.  The eyes in TLC by comparison look much better (which you can also see in his video).  There is a bit of a blur over everything and some of the ambient occlusion looks pretty bad.  There's already user-made .ini tweaks on the Steam forums to deal with some of these issues and using them does provide some improvement.

The real problem is the horrible controls.  There is no mouse control for the game menus and the keyboard controls are nonsensical.  They literally mapped the A, B, and Y keys of the Xbox 360 controller to the A, B, and Y keys of the keyboard to manipulate many of the menu functions in the game.  I've never seen the B key used to manipulate menus in a game before.  It's not a great innovation.

The inventory screen is completely changed from TLC's for the worse.  To do anything inventory related in this version you start with the Insert and Home keys to navigate tabs, then use the Delete and End keys to navigate sub-tabs, then switch to the arrow keys to navigate lists and sub-lists, then the A key wear, equip, or bind something, then B to exit out.  Sometimes Esc will get you back directly to the game, sometimes not.  It's really clunky.  The layout itself has a ton of wasted screen space on colors, tabs, and subtabs with only a small amount of screen real estate devoted to actually display the items you are carrying.

There is no mouse sensitivity adjustment.  When I first started playing in Oakvale just turning the camera was strikingly jarring.  I don't know why, I just finished Skyrim a few weeks ago and had no issue with swinging the camera around in that game, but here in Fable Anniversary I found it terribly jarring visually.  I thought maybe turning down the mouse sensitivity would help...but there's no way to do that.  Maybe this is just a personal thing that I'll get used to.

The oddness of combining orb gathering and spell use on the left shift still persists and is just as troublesome as it was in the original.  Blocking and dodging are on the middle mouse button.  Maybe that was fine 9 years ago when I played with a gaming mouse that actually had a middle mouse button, but today I have a scroll wheel there and that scroll wheel button is a terrible way to control such critical functions like block and dodge.  It's not as sensitive and fairly uncomfortable.

There is some key remapping available once you have loaded a game, but critical keys (like the A and B use to navigate the menus, attack, block, dodge, etc.) cannot be remapped.  I wish I could remap dodge and block to some of the other mouse buttons on my Death Adder 2013, but that's not possible.

Exiting game is probably the worst I've seen in any PC game in years.  You hit Esc, then A to select save game, arrow keys to choose a save slot, A to save, B to go back to the menu, hit the arrow down key 4 or 5 times to select Quit, A to quit, wait for a loading screen to the main menu, hit the arrow down key 7 or 8 times to select exit to Windows, hit A to exit. Every.Single.Time.You.Quit.The.Game.  In 2014 it should be substantially easier to save and quit a computer game.

Some of these control issues can be mitigated by using an Xbox 360 controller.  I happen to have one and tried it but I thought the quick menu to access the many expressions and inventory items to be atrocious.  There is no key remapping for either of the 2 controller layout options.

To sum up: I'm disappointed.  I expected better graphics.  For regular (non menu) gameplay the keyboard/mouse controls aren't too bad or too changed from the original but they certainly weren't updated or improved.  The inventory menu layout is overly complicated and the menu controls are abysmal.  It all works, mind you.  It's all functional.  But it's not very well done and absolutely mars a really great game.

As for stability, I've only played a little over 2 hours and haven't had any stuttering or other visual issues being reported on Steam forums.  No crashes either.  I have an i7-3770, 8 GB RAM, and an Nvidia GTX 770.

I wish I had waited for this come on sale on Thanksgiving or maybe Christmas. I still love Fable and still think it's a great game, but Fable Anniversary did not live up to expectations.  There's a really great game underneath the clunky interface and inventory menu system.  It's a shame that Fable Anniversary didn't really polish up Fable TLC and really make the game shine.

reviewText:
There is a large list of Cons for this game, and not too many pros.
There is no menu mouse support and the in-game mouse is very VERY wonky, they put almost no effort into porting it from Xbox with controls in mind.
The graphics are not a big enough improvement to warrent a 300% price increase from the Lost chapters.
The day one DLC that was not included with preorder is a thorn in the side of the gaming community. It is obviously already made, so add it into the game without trying to charge us more for this cash grab.
The modding support is a sham, with players only able to change textures and animations (Supposedly) I'm sure the community could find a way around that but we should be given what we were promised in ACTUAL modding support.

All in the all this remake feels like like a remake, and more a retextured cash grab that you should stay away. Instead spend that money to get Fable: The Lost Chapters on steam, it is still perfectly playable even 9 years later.

reviewText:
It is rare that a game can make me angry within three minutes of play but Fable Anniversary has managed to make me want to give up PC gaming within TWO minutes. This is a lazy, half-baked port if I ever saw one. Something as basic as mouse support for menus should have been included on day one. I wait, with anticipation, for weeks now to play this. I even considered buying The Lost Chapters on Steam to tide me over. I probably should have bought it and forgot about Fable Anniversary. How can I enjoy the immersive world of Fable when the menus are so awful and the game lags on my reasonably powerful PC? The chicken chaser developers have shown utter contempt to PC players with this port. They advertised this port as a 'favour' to all the loyal PC fans out there who have waited and waited. Lionhead and Microsoft shouldn't have given us the favour if they were not going to be bothered to do it properly.

EDIT:
The laggy graphics can be improved on NVIDA cards wtih a bit of rigging around. Improves experience greatly.

reviewText:
Bad Port, Terrible Controls, Same Old Game

Fable: The Lost Chapters was a wonderful game, but if you've already played it, you've already played this. This is nothing more than a high res texture/shader pack for Fable: TLC. This is not a full scale remake, leaving audio, animations and engine untouched. The character have been given higher detailed and higher resolution models, but they are stuck on the same old skeletons and use the same old animations. The worst offender are characters' eyes, which like the original game, still do not move. It looked weird 10 years ago, and it looks even weirder now. With the more realistic looking characters, with the old robotic movements, dead unmoving eyes, it really does give you the feeling of being trapped in some sort of fun house animatronic hell. The faces of the characters also feels like a downgrade from TLC, while they are higher resolution, most of the characters have rather ugly faces, and look a lot more generic than in TLC, losing a lot of their cartoonish look which gave them life in the first place.

It's also a bad port directly from Xbox, with absolutely no attempt at making PC controls. This game is practically unplayable with a mouse and keyboard, even if that's how you typically played Fable: TLC in the past. In-game controls can be remapped (only once in game, NOT in the main menu) but all UI controls are ripped straight from xbox, meaning you have to type A" "B" "X" "Y" on your keyboard in order to interact with the menus
date: and there is no option within the game to remap these. Other control flaws exist such as needing to press "Insert" and "Delete" to go to different pages in your inventory/journal.\n\nAs for the environments and lighting changes

reviewText:
Lengthy review ahead; skip to bottom for TL;DR version.

The review:
* General stuff: Alright, so in a PC port, they excluded a few rather *key* items. Obviously, the first major item on this list is mouse support in menus. However, you still CAN navigate the menus using the keyboard's arrow keys + 'A'/'B' keys for selection/back button. Although it's rather annoying, it IS there... so, there's that.
* Options: The other thing that got to me before I even got into game was the (lack of?) options for graphics. You can set a few basic options from low, medium, or high. Basically, there's really no graphical options for the game. That being said, for a port from a game that was based on Xbox 360 graphics, I really cannot complain. Is it better than the original? Of course. Is it modern PC graphics? No, not by a long shot. But hey, it's a port. It's not like they went out and hired an entire staff of PC programmers for this single game (I wish, though).
* Bugs/glitches: Well, again, for a port it's kind of 'to-be-expected'. Honestly, I'm kind of surprised about how many people are talking about this specifically. Does Darksouls get a bad rating because it natively cannot render 1080p, or display text/textures in HD? No. Everyone goes and downloads DSFix and then stops complaining. I really feel like this is something that people spend too much time on. I found that if I let the game load (e.g. I sat there for a few minutes), it would load the entire level and I'd continue without any disturbance of FPS issues. Later in the game this became extremely uncommon and within 4 hours of playing, I stopped experiencing this issue altogether. Other than a few brief run-ins with a laggy screen, I didn't experience any downsides of 'programming' on their behalf. (Note: I do have a gaming PC, I don't know if that makes a difference when experiencing these issues...)
* Overview: Overall, it still feels like the same Fable I played years ago. The dialouge is the same (whether you decide that's good/bad is up to you, I didn't even care that it wasn't HD... you really can't tell, stop ♥♥♥♥♥ing), so the story still really hits home. Everything you used to do? You can still do it. With the exception of some really broken exploits, of course. I was still easily able to navigate the game in my old manner; I had a Master Katana within the first hour (first few quests), and by the middle of the game (before Arena), I was donating hundreds-of-thousands- to the Temple of Avo for all the glory they could bestow onto me. Buy/Sell schemes still work on merchants, the house buying/selling still works, etc... it's pretty much all there. I didn't ever try the time-stop glitch, but only because I didn't need it due to buying/selling Emeralds in Oakvale (honestly why would you need to stop time when you can buy anything?).
* Combat: Alright, so I've been playing the whole game (yes, I completed Fable + TLC content) with a F310 Logitech controller. Honestly, combat is a little awkward, at first; having to hold 2 buttons (L2 trigger for lockon; R1 bumper for blocking) + pushing 'X' to attack, + rolling the thumbsticks for directional/camera changes is a BIT much, but after all, it's Fable... You can stop pretending you have to block attacks after you purchase Plate armor and upgrade your Health/Toughness. It becomes less hectic and becomes kind of mundane, but that's how the original one was as well (about to attempt Heric Mode), so again, I cannot complain. Magic use is a bit frustating too, as by default you can only have ONE magic spell readily castable. The way you cycle through them is R2 trigger + 'B', which becomes slow if you have a lot of spells and sometimes, you over-rotate spells and have to re-cycle through them just for the one you wanted... sometimes, in combat. Not fun.
* Other Thoughts: I pre-ordered this game, so I was given Scythe's Pack for free. The items it added are interesting and, to say the least, are fun to mess around with. They are not game-breaking and give no edge over someone who does not purchase the pack. Again, I played this game with a F310 Logitech controller and found it rather easy to control after a while of getting used to the controls. I played my first play-through on Normal mode and plan to play again on Heroic and go for 100%.

TL;DR version:
* I do recommend this game, but remember, it is a port and is not designed for the PC. Please, do not hold it to the same expectations as a newly released PC game. Also, if you happen to encounter some of *many* bugs/glitches, instead of complaining and whining, maybe contact Lionhead support and let them know? Help them fix the problem so we can all enjoy the game. Use a controller for the gameplay, it'll make your life easier. Enjoy the game.
