reviewText:
Fable Anniversary is the exact same game as Fable: The Lost Chapters (a great game) with somewhat improved graphics. Well, almost exactly the same... Technically they changed the menu layouts. Unfortunately, not for the better.

It's pretty clear that this wasn't intended to be released for the PC originally. This new version is NOT mouse friendly. Unless you use a controller you'll have to rely heavily on the keyboard for most things, which I personally find frustrating; when there are a lot of things that would be much simpler if I could use a mouse. This isn't the only issue with the Anniversary version of Fable either.

The picture looks blurry and washed out on the PC. There is a fix that resolves this issue completely, but it involves some very minor editing of a couple game files. It's fairly simple, but shouldn't be necessary.

As stated though; textures, faces, and such are improved noticeably. A couple of the faces (like the hero as a kid and Maze's) look a bit odd to me though. The only reason to get version is if you really want a the modestly improved graphics and the added outfits & weapons in the DLC. Just be prepared to deal with the mouseless menus and to fix those files I mentioned to clear the picture.

reviewText:
I'm writing this quick review to counter a lot of the negative reviews. I've almost completed the game with every side quest done, and I haven't found any of the issues people are talking about:
- Gamebreaking bugs. Not seen any at all. Plus, thanks to the new save systems you can reload often if something happens.
- Horrible optimisation. Runs easily at 60fps even on my sub-par laptop. Game looks a lot more pretty than regular fable
- Awful camera controls. The camera controls are almost exactly as it was in the original Fable, which I played extensively as a child and had no complaints with. Maybe new people to the game aren't so happy with this? But it seems absolutely fine and easily playable. I was using an Xbox controller to play, and it works seemlesly.

Not worth the full price, but it was on sale for £5 and so I definitely recommend it if you can grab it on a sale.

reviewText:
I love Fable the lost chapters (original version) I like this version too except the major let down is that the controls are so dumbed down for the keyboard and mouse that I can not modify them much to my preferences and it is actually more complicated. I just started playing and I am already frustrated about the controls, I was really looking forward to this game too. I personally do not use game controllers for the pc due to the fact that I don't have one don't need one. Anyone who is like that will most likely run into the same problem as me. The main aspect about this version I do like though is the dlc and updated graphics. On a whole I think this game is definitly worth playing though, especially if you have a game controller for the pc.

I also recommend  just playing the original fable the lost chapters, due to the fact that I have noticed many crashing and loading and lagging issues that I have  experienced on the Xbox 360 version of this game. Therefore I have decided to change my opinion on my recomendation, as I believe that this game could have been atleast improved from the Xbox 360 version, since it is on the pc.

Also There are many similarities that are familiar too the original Fable the lost chapters in the mechanics that I have used in the past for the pc specifically. There is also already mods for the original fable the lost chapters as well that has been out for ages.

On a whole I honestly feel pretty nuetral about this version of the game, I was disapointed, but I am also glad that I still have fun playing this game after all these years.  :)

reviewText: The original Fable holds a place in my heart, and the idea of a HD remaster of this game should have been a pleasant, nostalgic experience. However, due to clunky programming, thrown together UI, frequent clipping issues and overall lazy efforts on behalf of the developement team, this game is only a glimps of what it could have been. The core game is still in tact, and just as enjoyable (and recommended) but the original has had a lot more love put into it and is more deserving of your money.\n\nFable remains a very enjoyable experience, and worthy of multiple playthroughs. Either version is worth picking up, as the remasters pros are equalled by it's cons. Pick this up if you're a hardcore fan or if it's on sale, otherwise the original remains cheaper and more authentic.

This reveiw is coming for a slighlty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off DIE HARD fable the lost chapters fan.

i played fable the lost chapters as a young child more then once probablly 9-10 times all the way through and i loved it to no end i would have given it a 9/10 and have nothing super bad to say about it but fable anniversary ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off quite a few times, first it changed the inventory form pressing esc to F which i thought was pretty ♥♥♥♥ing stupid and after 12 hours i'm still not used to it, but the worst part of it is the ♥♥♥♥ING INVENROTY GLITCH. i hate this glitch to no end and it never seemed to stop once it started, it would take your inventory either all the way to the left, bottom, or top and wouldn't let you move it. in order to fix it you had to save, reload and bam its gone. nothing to serious right well if you in thr middle of a quest it starts it all over again if you didn't finish the quest first this game has been out a year and this glitch is still in it like WTF WHY FIX IT ALREADY.

reviewText:
Fable Anniversary....You were the chosen one! I had so much hope for you!

The original PC version (TLC) was beyond a doubt one of the greatest, underrated games of its time. The pile of, well frankly, ♥♥♥♥ that has been made available on Steam is a pale comparison to the game of old. Sure the graphics are a little bit smoother, but that is the one single thing that has been improved on. The actual graphics themselves are no better than they were 10 years ago. Couple this with the fact that the game stutters it's way through sections for no apparent reason other than that that is what it wants to do. The controls are horrendous unless you use a game pad, with no option to key bind for the keyboard and mouse, you're left with some un-intuitive system that seemingly was designed by someone with no background in PC gaming.

For Lionhead's sake I hope they patch this quick, they're losing a large audiences attention very quickly with this. Pull your finger out and patch it, before the modders beat you to it!

No vote until patched...

/rant

reviewText: I saw that this game had some mixed reactions and I honestly don't understand why. I like that this is just a touched up version of the original. That is what a remaster is after all.\n\nWhile Fable II is my favorite in the series, Fable was a go-to on my Xbox before The Lost Chapters came to PC. At it's time, it felt like the first game where you could just do anything you want. The game is very light-hearted and secretly cruel. In this version, they've updated the graphics for modern PCs (while still looking like Fable). They added native Xbox 360 controller support, and they've added Steam achievements. I'm really impressed.

reviewText: Who will you become? Fable Anniversary is the re-release of the original game that was created in 2004 and is bundled with all the extra content that was subsequently released a year later. The first thing anyone who has played the original Fable will notice is how ginormous the technical upgrade for this game is. It is far more than just an HD remake, It is a complete redesign on the graphical style of Fable with an absolutely impressive lighting system and a recrafting of the original textures along with a new streamlined control system modeled after the much better control scheme of Fable 2, but only those with a controller will be able to enjoy the new controls as the controls for the keyboard are still the same as the original. If you have played the original Fable and enjoyed it, don’t miss out on this wonderful experience. If you are new to Fable give it a shot, it’s a very charming, humorous and SUPER British RPG game that is absolutely delightful. Though its promise of choice is not as flushed out as it could have been that is no reason to miss out on such a unique game.

reviewText:
I'd recommend this game to any fan of the genre.

Looking past Molyneux's exaggerations, and embellishments, Fable offers a unique story that holds up well to this day.

The primary antagonist is still, in my opinion, one of the best villians of all time.

I played the original Fable on Xbox, I play The Lost Chapters on PC, I played Anniversary on 360, and I've played this.
I would highly recommend the game to anyone interested. What have you got to lose?

reviewText: This game seems to be getting a lot of bad reviews, but my experience has been nothing but positive. I haven't encountered a single bug, glitch or crash, if the game had problems they've apparently worked them. The graphics and animation look fine to me, better than I was expecting, but then again I'm not the type of person who expects every blade of grass to be rendered in stunning detail in order to enjoy a game. The UI and controls all look and work fine and the menus are easy to navigate.  Keep in mind, I use a controller so I can't speak to the keyboard/mouse use.\n\nI never player the original Fable but I was a big fan of both Fable II and III on Xbox 360 so it was nice to add to that experience. I've already got over 50 hours into it and I'm already looking forward to a second playthrough. As I said, I never played the original so I can’t say how much difference there is, but if you haven’t played it than it’s definitely worth the money in my opinion.

Would definitely recommend this to anybody who enjoyed Fable 1/The Lost Chapters. Make no mistake, this is Fable 1 all over again with really nothing new other than a visual overhaul. You're getting the authentic Fable experience, quirks and all. I bought this game, on sale, right as I was getting ready to play through Fable 1 again anyway. reviewText:
In short: This is a great game. Any bugs or glitches that were there, are no longer there so don't worry about that when purchasing this game. It has a great storyline, one of the best combat systems, a huge arsenal of weaponry/spells, and a great system for customizing your character.

Storymode: The storymode in the game is one of my all time favorites in rpg's. Getting scarred as a child, then living a life where you thirst for revenge. And like every story, when seeking revenge, betrayal is not far behind.

Combat Style: I've played a lot of rpg's and this is a combat style that I wish more fantacy rpg's will focus on. You can easily organize your massive library of spells to work with your combat when needed. Unlikeother games I found this one a lot easier to defend myself against enimies, yet still gave me a challenge if I wasn't paying enough attention.

Character Customization: As you play the game you begin to aquire more clothing/armour, as well find some tattoo parlours/hairsalons. With clothing you can mix and match or easily set it to the presets. Each set of clothing not only helps you with your armour, but with how you look to other npc's, Rather you're trying to attract a babe, or scare a gaurd the Algorythm in doing so is very simple to understand. When it comes down to tattoo/hairstylists, there are several locations in doing so. Each location has different styles, and certain artists don't have a stationary building so you are able to go on a random walk in the woods and end up getting a haircut and a new tattoo along the way.

Bugs and Glitches: I didn't buy the game when it first came out so my following statement is how the game is currently. Mind you I 100% the game so I was still able to experience everything, and I'm not reviewing this whilst I'm in the middle of the game. The only bugs that I did get are the following: Getting stuck between two objects, when this happened I simply tp'd out and continued on (This happened only once through my entire play through). Near the end of the game I tried to kill an enemy with my sword and when doing so my game crashed, I resolved this problem by killing him with my bow instead. After doing so I had 0 problems with that quest and at no other point did I have that problem. After I 100% the acievments I was awarded the achivment via game but I wasn't via steam. Which is frustraiting but nothing to cry over. In simple terms the game has very minimal bugs, all of which were easily resolved.

reviewText:
Well now, Where to begin.

I'm not a fable veteran, this was the first version I've played, so if you're expected a nostalgic ramble about childhood memories, you're out of luck.

What I am is a roleplaying veteran, and I enjoyed this game.

Fable is a very tounge-in-cheek romp through a pile of cliches and injokes, self-effacing in its humour and outragous in its actions. Fable is geniune enjoyment for the pure sense of enjoyment. If you are a fan of RPGs and good humour and are looking for a casual game, this is the game for you.


Pros:
Easy and flexible control scheme
Hilarious gameplay

Cons:
Lack of challenge
limited character options
railroad plot

reviewText:
Edits for the previous updates: I won't be spending any addition money on this title soon, and I don't think you should either, unless its on sale. The updates have been coming in, and we have recieved what we demanded in a quality game. This still doesn't change the fact that I feel the original remains superior.

There are a few big issues I still see in this title. The graphics, while improved from the original, fail to meet the current standards for games of this art style. There are many textures that don't even meet the debatable quality of the rest of the game. Many of the characters that looked fine in the original, now look disgusing.

Mouse support on the menus is enough to make me consider playing it more, but I'm experiencing frame-rate issues for no obvious reason. A shame, as I have complete the original many times, and want to play the harder difficulties that Anniversary offers.

TL;DR My opinion on the game has increased immensly from its original release date, but it has yet to meet the standards it should. If the game continues to be improved by the developers, then it may just get my approval someday.

reviewText: First off I have been a long, long, long term fan of the Fable series.  Always loved Lionhead, but this is just broken.  Mouse/keyboard is a fail.  Worse is the game is jerky, laggy, and crashes.  It is not my PC, as I have had no issue ever playing other much more hardware demanding games.  This port is the nail in the coffin for me and Lionhead.  I'll probably still play due to nostalgia of the old days, but I really wish I could get my money back.  Playing this port brings me back to the days of DOS games and their mad user interface.  Always loved the Fable series, until now.  Please fix the issues, that should have never happened, and I would gladly re-review.  Buy it for the old days, and yell at it for the utter failure of an attempt to update a really great game.

reviewerDisplayName: Vaping is Cool and not Edgy
reviewText:
Fable: The Lost Chapers, was one of my favourite games as a child. When I heard about Fable Anniversary, I bought it withotut expecting much; I thought it would just be a HD remaster. Maybe fix some of the glitches. What I got was:

+ Improved shading.
+ Improved sound quality

Improved texture resolution and models, though the faces are all hideous.

- Interface that's about as user-friendly as forks being jammed under your toenails.
- No mouse control in menus.
- HORRIBLY clunky camera that seems to have trouble going around corners without jumping around.
- Sound cutting off and crackling whenever it feels your headset and/or ears aren't being tortured enough.
- Random Crashes
- Combined key commands that shouldn't have been combined- such as dodge/rolling
- Not being able to edit all of the controls without digging around in the files

Fable Anniversary is not worth the $35 price tag. The original Fable:TLC is superior in every way, unless you put graphics over gameplay. The graphical improvments are not enough to make up for the technical trainwreck that is Fable Anniversary. This is a shoddy port that simply feels unfinished. Alot of work has to be put into it before I would consider it supeior to the classic in any way.
voteText: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
My sympathies to anyone that shelled out the £27 for this game expecting a quality remake. Let this be a lesson to us all.

This remake has been designed for a console and not PCs and the shoddy porting does not justify the price tag. Porting a console game for PCs and not redesigning the control interface to take advantage of the versitility of keyboards is just outright lazy. The developers should be ashamed.

The simplified interface is a big problem. My impression is they designed it to be attractive instead of functional. Menus do not support mice and are awkward to navigate.

Another couple of flaws with this game are hard-coded keybinds and non-reprogrammable key functions. First off they are scattered all over the keyboard [Menu navigation keys especially]. Secondly if you are using directional keys you will find that a lot of the neighboring keys cannot be rebound. Unless you are born with a third, usuable arm it is difficult to use the controls effectively.

Lastly, for a game that is focused around cosmetic improvements it does not offer much fine-tuning for the graphics. It offers very few options [Which is a huge problem for lower-end computers, since minimal settings are still overstrained by the games poor optimization]. The only way to modify specific graphical features is to root around the files and modify configs. Players should NEVER have to do this.

I have no found no notable qualities that makes this game superior to the original Fable.

P.S - You can take your enforced Depth of Field and Bloom and shove it up your asses. If I wanted those on all the time I would just save my GPU the trouble and smear grease on my screen. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

reviewText:
Fable is one of my favorite game series of all time. If you liked the original, picking up the remaster is a no-brainer. It's funny how little it seems upgraded until you fire up the old version and are reminded how old it actually is. The graphics are actually MUCH better now, not just in terms of poly count and textures, but also in the lighting and post processing.

Fable probably won't play well on a keyboard and mouse. I have always just used a controller on my PC to play it. The 360 version works great. I love that they also ported over the control scheme from Fable 2 and 3 so you select either that or the classic Fable controller setup.

Now, Lionhead: WHERE IS FABLE 2 FOR THE PC?!?!

reviewText:
I've not plaied any of the Fable series before this one, and I must say this game was well made with quite alot effort and precission.

It's a classic ARPG game put in a 3d world, where you need to complete certain quests to get along with the storyline. I've got used to gameplay quite fast, either with keyboard or gamepad.

At most i've liked beautifull landscape, where you walk arround trees on an adventure, and feel like you are in some kind of a wonderland - just beautifull. Also there's a narrator that often commentates when you need to acquire some items or when you've finnished the quest.

There's also several outpost camps with different merchants(traders), where you can buy goods for an exchange of your gold you've collected through the game.


Fable Anniversary is definatelly worth buying if you like to play this genre of games. Buy this game as it's definatelly worth it's money.

reviewText:
As much as I loved the original Fable TLC, I can't say I'm really happy.
Even though I enjoyed myself, I simply can't stand the fact that it feels like a total rip-off to me.


I expected way more of Fable Anniversary, but the only thing that seems to be new here are the menu screens, textures and lighting. It honestly feels more like a retexture and lighting mod than an old favorites' rebirth.
That's not as bad if you didn't count for the horrible menu's, tedious controls and exact same animations as the original version.

Maybe my expectations were to high, but I thought this game would have enhanced controls, finetuned for PC. I expected quick and easy PC-friendly menu's. I expected fresh animations and even added content. When I put down 26 euro's for this, I expected a newly remade experience with the old story and gameplay. Instead I got the exact same game that I already played 8 years ago, with some new textures slapped on top of it.

If you really want to play Fable TLC ( And I really think you should :D ), just stick to the original.
The textures aren't as new as in Fable Anniversary, but at least they look like they belong there.
To me it feels wrong to play this version, knowing that I have a perfectly good copy in my closet that has served me 6 enjoyable replays.


tl;dr: Don't buy this, get the original Fable TLC instead.
voteText: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game fails on so many levels and I could not honestly recommend that any serious PC gamers buy this game until it has some serious patches and enhancements made to it.
Firstly, IT IS THE MOST BLATANTLY OBVIOUS CONSOLE PORT I'VE EVER SEEN.
> The Main Menu does not have mouse support.
> Key rebindings can only be accessed in-game, and not through the main menu.
> Key rebindings are extremely limited, with hard-locked keys for certain things, and dual functionality keys.
> The key rebindings were far more extensive, customisable and USEFUL in Fable: The Lost Chapters.
> The in-game Inventory/Quest/etc. menu also lacks mouse support, and is terribly designed for a PC game - with poor use of real-estate, bad structure, etc.

Secondly, THIS BARELY EVEN QUALIFIES AS A REMAKE.
> It is a HD remaster at best.
> Some graphics options that were available in Fable: The Lost Chapters are mysteriously missing in Fable Anniversary, namely Anti-aliasing (I believe Fable Anniversary is hard-locked to some sort of FXAA  - which results in the game looking like a blurry, murky mess).
> The only real improvements that I can make out are texture improvements, some mesh improvements (though I was expecting a little better, especially for characters faces), and some nice shadows/post-processing effects.
> Due to the lack of a decent and accessible anti-aliasing, I actually find Fable: The Lost Chapters more aesthetically pleasing, because the image is sharper and not as murky or blurred.
> On my 16:10 (Native Resolution 1440x900) monitor regular gameplay (not just cutscenes) also has thick black lines at the top and bottom of the screen. I am uncertain as to whether or not this is intentional, and whether or not 16:9 monitors get this as well.

All in all, this is a terrible PC port. It needs a decent bit of work before I could honestly recommend it.
Totalbiscuit (the YouTube Channel host) also did a good video outlining some flaws of the game and comparing it to Fable: The Lost Chapters.

P.S: If you are an Australian citizen like I am, and you are unhappy with this purchase, I believe you can ask for a refund if you have played less than 14 hours of the game. Under Australian law the vendor is REQUIRED to provide you with as refund if the product is not deemed 'Fit for Purpose', which I would argue it is not, as it does not fulfil it's purpose of being a fully functional PC game.

reviewText:
As much as I love the game - both the original xbox version and the later released TLC, this Anniversary edition is not worth the money - yet.

Coming off just finishing TLC again a few months ago, I honestly don't think the new textures are all that much of an improvement. Sadly, that was the main grab for most of us. Imagine TLC with a higher polygon count, and that's what we are dealing with for the most part. There is a bit more detail on the armor, however the charater models seem to somehow look even worse. These graphics may have been mid-end 5 years ago.

Playing with a 360 controller, the new menu seems a bit clunky and the camera is definitely wobbly. Never bothered with KB+M, but I can definitely see why it is frustrating. Many of the glitches and issues from the original xbox release 10 years ago are still prevalent, unfortunately. Nothing game-breaking, but animations are far from smooth and the new combat system is not what I would call 'intuitive'.

One of the things that really disappoints me is how simple the achievements are. Nearly every achievement outside of the story-related ones give you two ways to attain it, making them all incredibly easy. Unlock all demon doors... Or flip the bird at one locked one" is hardly anything to be proud of.

Hopefully the devs step up to the plate and fix some of the more severe issues
date: such as the KB+M compatibility. I'd love to see some additional content and better textures
recommended: but if they didn't do it while 'developing' this re-release

reviewText:
Seems similar to the original, with the same plot and everything. Doesn't seem like anything new has been added so far, but I suppose that's because it's just remastered graphics?

The graphics seem ok, not fantastic. The faces seem very... ugly. I'm sure my character wasn't that ugly in the first game, and other characters also seem to have lumpy, mishapen potatoes for heads. some people have weird eyes that seem to glow, which is odd. All the cutscenes and animations like in the spell book (when you go to upgrade abilities, you see a little imge of the spell in the bottom right corner) seem to be from the old game, and are quite blurred. Which is odd, seeing as this is supposed to be an upgraded graphics game.

The controls are abysmal. I can't remember the original fable have these weird controls. It's very difficult to shoot bows and dodge and everything at once, which I can't remember happening in the original. The menus are terriblle and nothing is consistent. (As default) You walk using WASD, then the menu switches to using insert/home, delete/end and arrow keys.
No mouse is allowed in inventory/menu screen. It just makes it more difficult to use, and seems like a crappy console port.

Aging and scars are terrible. As a young adult in this game, I shouldn't look like an 80 year old man who's been whipped and tortured all his life. The slightest nudge of a leaf, falling gently from a tree, causes horrific and irrevesible scaring over 90% of your hero's body. I'm all for the rights of people with disabilities and disorders, but surely this guy shouldn't be a hero and would be better employed stuffing feathers into pillows or some other profession where you're unlikely to be maimed because a butterfly looked at you funny.

reviewText: I was never much of a fan of the sequals, however the first Fable and its expansion will always be one of my favorite games, one that i'll never get bored of. When I heard that there was a game that was exactly the same but with a graphics/physics update I thought great! Pre-ordered it without a second though. I've been quite disapointed with it though. Considering the graphics are the ONLY update to the game, which is priced at a hefty £26.99 I was expecting amazing graphics, although the graphics are better than its predesessor, they are by no means impressive. Rocky terrain is still completely smooth, and the game for some reason is quite blurry. Not even close to being worth £26.99. The game is also an obvious console port. You have to use the keyboard to navigate the menu's which can be quite frustrating and you are unable to bind the keys to the mouse, for the price tag its unacceptable and just lazy. I've already had an unrecoverable crash.\n\nIf you are a die hard Fable fan im sure you will buy this anyway. If you havnt played before, I suggest waiting until the game is at a more reasonable price. In conclusion this is a slight graphics update, with a lazy console port feel and leaves the impression that the developers just wanted to make a bit of easy money from a known title.

reviewText:
updates 3-4:
while they finally enabled the mouse for all menu's the menu system is still jacked up big time.
they fixed some of the graphic issues with clothing and clipping with skin/underwear or whatever the base textures are.

- still need to work on combining all menu's so that keyboard and mouse changes can be made from main menu, instead of being forced to do it while playing the game.
- still need to upgrade skeletons for male characters, specially PC; which currently looks like a walking toothpick, and mesh morphing.
- still need to work on invisible items that are still somehow selectable... (at least one glitch like this with the haircut shop in bowerstone).
- still need to work on updating intro videos or get rid of them, both logo and intro to main menu are still pixelated bigtime, still no excuse for this lack of work, its just pathetic.
- still need to work on invisible walls that dont match the terrain.
- need to work on how stat/equpiment/etc. menu's are laid out and work.
- still need to work on GUI sizes, should all be included with the hotbar 'options' which really isnt a option right now.
- still need to fix blue plastic look for player character.
- still need to fix animations (would be less of an issue if skeleton on PC was made more masculine instead of stickman).
- still need to fix quest text, given quest text is non-informative... unless you remember exactly what you were doing when you start the game and load/continue a save, the quest text is so vague as to be completely useless... it needs to be fixed or removed entirely.
- random item pickup respawns for house objects that are actually searchable, also you would think that you would be able to use those objects (shelves and cubaords/etc.) in your own house, to store stuff or to search for what might have been there previously.
- better modding support for textures/animations/skeletons/etc. so people dont have (forced?) to use texmod to play/use mods at all.
- some textures and item placements need to be updated (delivery boxes, garden walls, 'retaining' walls).

still major work needs to be done on this game before it is worth spending ANY money on for PC... the original port is still 100 times better than anniversary.

the modding DLC that is 'free' still has nothing in it to download... even if we wanted to mod the game we currently cannot because there are no tools available via the free DLC download, there isnt even a place setup to add override or mods for the game to use (plus no options in-game yet to load override or mods for the game at all)

MS/LionHead have a TON and a half issues to fix still, specially for those of us who where hoping to mod the game.

final thought:
even with the (3rd?) update, it is not yet worth actually buying still.

reviewText:
I want to, oh how do I want to, but I can't write a positive review for this. It runs fine, the graphics are nice, but here's the thing...You don't play a game for graphics, I don't care who you are but if you give a positive review for this game, I'm calling bs. I'll give a few pros and cons that I have encountered in playing this.

Pros:

Graphics are better than the origional/Lost chapters.

DLC stuff (Trust me I'm scraping the bottom of the barrel with these pros for this game)

Personal Pro: You can dress up as a guard and beat up people with a Lute, I love that.

Personal Pro: It stays true to the story/doesn't add extra bs to an already told story that isn't needed.

Now for the Cons:

Buggy menus, I cannot tell you how many people I've talked to where its impossible to buy certian items cause, when I press down on my keyboard, it would instantly snap back up. I am forever Chicken Chaser with a normal haircut and normal beard cause of this. Hopefully this will be fixed one day but as for now, not happy. One other thing I nearly forgot, you have to have at least one item in one of the equipment tab if you accedently buy too much and you want to sell a few back. Sell all your sellable items in one of the tabs and you won't be able to get back into it without exiting the traider's menu and retalking to them, which if it was any proof in the origional Fable or The Lost Chapters, they usually decided to talk your ears off before you could talk to them agian, leaving you to simply wave till they shut up.

The animations are daited and it shows. Sure, The mouths move more naturally but holy ♥♥♥♥ you have one of those demon children stare at you or one of those really stiff guards talk to you its almost like your in a world filled with robots.

Buggy Combat, I found this out fighting wisper and the wasp queen. I would hit wisper several times then suddenly she decided she didn't want to be hurt anymore, actually blocking some strong attacks till I eased up on her and decided to put away then requip my sword, giving her a free hit on me in the process. The wasp queen was a diffrent story, after hitting her several times with my Crossbow, suddenly she was invinceible to it and I couldn't use it anymore, even after unequipping and requpping the crossbow, thank god they start you out with lighting as a spell, though I nearly died to her cause of this. Agian, may be fixed, but I never once got hit in the origional fable unless I made the mistake of trying to block a power shot, or my mana shield went down. Not. Happy.

Now I understand that's four pros and Three cons, but keep in mind that two of those Pros are personal and those cons are pretty damn big. Let me put it how I explained to my friends about the Fable franchise.

Fable, the origional fable, was a nice girl, and when she told me about The Lost Chapters, she was very adult" when she talked about it

reviewText:
I'm not going to write a conventional review on this game but I will leave my thoughts after playing it for about an hour.

WARNING: This will be a rant in most places, but I will do my best.

What I liked:

- The Nostalgia: This is the reason I bought the game, and in most places, it delivered, at least aesthetically.

- The Graphics: This is a bit of a double-edged sword... They look impressive enough (certainly an upgrade) but there are issues.

What I disliked:

- The Voice Acting: This is only a small point I suppose, but something miffed me about it... Much of this has remained from the original game, which is fine, absolutely fine, but the very first opening cutscene seems to have been re-recorded or remastered or they've done something to it, and it sounds terrible. The actor does not sound enthusiastic about this heroic tale that is about to unfold, and not only that, the sound quality is awful. Not sure if it's a problem on my end but it wasn't terrific, and for an opening cutscene I would expect something to excite me about indulging in my nostalgia and playing one of my favourite childhood games again, but in HD - the concept grabbed me and I threw my wallet at them, I really wish I hadn't now and spent it on something else, and I will explain why in the next point.

- The Menu, Inventory, etc......... : I have no idea who designed this menu, but I do not think they were human. It is just so fiddly, so much so that it irritates me too much to even want to play the game. You can assign things, sure, but doing that takes some real jiggery-pokery, a little too much if you ask me. It's like trying to crack the da vinci code, when all I want is to eat an apple pie from my potions and produce tab. It has NO MOUSE OPTIMISATION. This is the big one everyone is talking about and I feel it needs to be heard. The original game had perfectly fine mouse optimisation. To call the game a HD remake and not have mouse optimisation is absolutely mind blowing to me. I know HD more so focuses on the graphics, but if its a testament to the original, I would expect everything to be in place that was originally, such as being able to use your mouse to select things in a menu... When I loaded the game up I was all excited to get stuck in, but my heart sank when I tried to use my mouse and realised I could not. That was the point where I realised that this would be a bad port, and it was from the very start.

- The Options Menu: You are able to keybind some things... When you actually get into the game, mind you. But not the attack function, block function or anything important... The controls are fine for me, as I said previously. I can get on with them fine, it's a perfect setup for me. But for other people that's probably not the case, it's definitely something that should be there, why? Because Fable: The Lost Chapters had it. You could keybind anything.

It's a terrible port at the moment. I really hope that a patch is released to make things easier for people who want to enjoy it on their PCs with a keyboard and mouse. I enjoyed Fable: The Lost Chapters perfectly fine on my PC, in fact I have done at least 4 seperate playthroughs of the game because I enjoyed it that much. This was one of my main childhood games. I feel as if its ruined, all because of this console focus they have gone with. Play it with a controller" some people are saying - no. Why should I? If you're going to release a PC port of a game
date: do it right. I play on a PC. If I wanted to play it on a console I'd buy the console version of the game. I don't.\n\nThe Graphics: As mentioned before
hoursPlayed: the graphics do look okay to me. They didn't exactly blow me away
voteText: but they are certainly an upgrade

column16: and the graphics options do not give you much freedom to do anything either.\n\nAt this point I am terribly disappointed and would not recommend to any like-minded PC gamers like myself. If you can enjoy the game with a console controller
column17: fine. You will probably have a blast

reviewText: The gameplay has not aged anywhere near as well as one would hope; and the Anniversary edition does little to fix that.  Beyond some clunky control issues; there's some very clear art direction issues that wind up with a world that, while technically superior, sports worse character models and design amplified by a terrible new lighting system that seems to show off all the flaws.\n\nIf you liked the original Fables : TLC - stick with that; you'll find nothing new here.

reviewText:
Okay, so this is actually a little funny. I *forgot* I already reviewed this game.
I was actually so annoyed at the time, i feel like I didn't quite explain enough.
SO. Allow me to clarify. First things I must adress: This was promised to be a complete recoding of the original game, from the ground up. Bull.
I played a couple hours into the storyline, and here's what I experienced; Exactly the same thing as the one I had for the Original XBox, with LESS playability. In fact, every glitch from the original game is still in this! ALL of the awful Voice Acting and Poorly timed SFX I remember from a game system with the memory capacity of a large potato. Good going, Capaldi! I mean it. Getting hit in this game is like someone grunting gently AFTER an ♥♥♥♥♥♥. It sounds and looks just as ridiculous as it used to. It was so incredibly poorly ported, I would wish I just bought the XBox just to buy the XBox version... If this game wasn't so horrible in general. The first update of the game? Compatibility. They didn't even bother to give us bloody mouse support! They actually never will. The keys weren't even configurable until around the third update, I think!
And what I'm about to say is true. No, it isn't the result of a bad or old computer. No, I don't have an oudated graphics card, full cache or some other nonsense. It's just awful. I can hardly walk around, after trying literally every fix I could find, I still walk around like a crippled puppy who also happens to be an epeleptic. That's not an off analogy either, it's really annoying to watch. It's ONLY character based. Enemies and NPCs are not affected unless I am moving. And apparently, there are many people experiencing similar issues... Alright, so. Assuming somehow the god-forsaken stuttering was fixed, and a mouse was useable.. I still would want to rip this stupid game OUT of my computer with my bare hands, defying the laws of reality, and visibly destroy it beyond repair. But somehow... Someone already did it.
Here's what I mean. Nothing was changed. NOTHING. I can't emphasise this enough. The textures are STILL pretty ♥♥♥♥-poor. It's ugly. Literally one of the only new things this game has to offer is STILL god-awful!  The teeth look like someone grabbed a chunk of burning, texture glitched wood from Skyrim and shoved it in their gums. The new DLC? ALL RE-USED TEXTURES. The second out of the three new features in the game use textures already found in the stupid game, save for maybe one or two sets. And those look like slightly modified base textures with Balverine fur strapped on them. I'm almost positive that they just took the original Fable, spit on it after eating rancid tuna, rubbed it with their sleeve and considered it polished. After this, they proceeded to gently hammer the disk until miraculously, it worked on PC.
Now for my final statement.. This is the first game that has EVER made me feel genuinely ripped-off. It's almost like they're punishing me for liking the original game. Why, in a remake, would you take OUT features that made the followup arguably BETTER than the sequel? And as much as I'd like to get a refund for this piece of trash, Steam's return policy has kind of.. well. It's not ♥♥♥♥ing possible! So, I'm stuck with this filth in my library. Forever. Imagine that. Sorry about all the caps for emphasis, but this used to be my favorite game. I loved Jack of Blades, all of the humor and hard choices. But really, now it's just redundant and annoying. There was no effort put into this, I'm almost sure.
And again, sorry for seeming so butthurt. But I am genuinely upset.

reviewText:
This is like a perfect example of what could've gone wrong if a pc version was an afterthought.
No mouse support, numerous amount of issues, terrible interface and some questionable graphical 'upgrades' such as facial expressions, let's face it most of the time they are pretty confusing at best, i have no problem buying it, since you know fable:tlc is still one of my favorite games up to date, the only reason for me to buy this is that i couldn't do it back in the day, so here i am 9 years later paying my respect to the awesomeness that is fable:tlc.

Also the trade between mouse support and mod support which is according to some sources is not even remotely good, is like trading your skin for a jacket to cover it, best decision of 2014, bravo.

So unless you are under a heavy load of nostalgia and don't have a problem playing the game with a gamepad, don't even bother, it's simply not worth your money and the original version is far,far superior, yeah, that one, which is 9 years old.

reviewText: The epitomy of bad and lazy PC ports. Mouse and keyboard support aren't arbitrary features that you tier in priority. Its the standard input method of PC as a platform. Its not a convenience, its a neccesity. To add almost insult to injurty not only are the bad keybinding randomly assigned (as if Lionhead had their cat walk over the keyboard to assign menu nav keys) but NONE of them are rebindable. Like the game is literally unplayable unless you buy a $40 accessory to go with your $35 game.\n\nThe biggest crime here is the original Fable on PC, Fable: The Lost Chapters had one of the best PC ports I had played. The heyboard and mouse controls were so smooth and combat system reworked for said inputs that I would argue that the PC version of F:TLR was not only better performance wise but its gameplay was superior to the Xbox original. I had preordered Fable Anniversary hoping for just a prettier version of F:TLR I could play through, instead I got this garbage game that isn't fit for being released on Steam. I seriously regret purchasing this title.

reviewText:
Don't buy this. If you're looking for a wonderful yet silly RPG, go get Fable TLC.

This is what Fable TLC has that Fable Anniversary doesn't.
1. A cartoony appearance aesthetic that aged well and doesn't look ugly or creepy.
2. An intuitive menu system.
3. An extensive key-mapping system that includes the whole keyboard and any extra buttons your mouse may have.

Given that, other than those three points, there are no differences between the two, I will repeat: Don't buy this. Buy or dig up Fable TLC.

reviewText:
One step forward, 10 steps back pretty much sums up this retexture.

Unfortunately this is a rather poor Xbox One port, that removes all of the good aspects of the original Lost Chapters PC version. Mouse functionality is no longer available in menus, instead navigation is controlled though the Home, End, Insert & Delete keys. You then make a selection using the A" (!?) key.

Whilst basic key rebinding is available
date: the main abilities are locked and cannot be reasssigned - block and dodge are both set to the mouse wheel which makes combat really fiddly for mouse and keyboard. The control scheme was clearly designed for use with an Xbox  controller.\n\nThe game seems to use built in FXAA that cannot be toggled off
recommended: which gives the game a blurry
hoursPlayed: unfocused look hiding a large amount of the  higher resolution textures.\n\nUntil large improvements are patched into this game
voteText: save your money and play the arguably much better original that was actually designed to be played on the PC."

reviewText:
0/5
A long term fan of Fable , and now, a disappointed one..
I remember the magical xmas I got my first Fable for my Xbox. I was excited, I locked myself into my room and pulled an all nighter, I was blissful. Happy memories about Fable II and Fable III as well.

So needless to say I was jumping up and down when I finally heard Lionhead would be bringing the Anniversary to PC, I immediately pre-ordered it and started counting the days, so this weekend when I finally got to launch it I had chills down my spine as I saw the old intro's and heard the old familiar voices and music..
but my enjoyment came to a bitter end, as soon as I started looking for my free DLC that should've been included in the Pre-purchase bonus, not the fact that I still haven't found it, but the _AWFUL_, _HORRIBLE_ straight from console to pc-port they made, I mean, I'm just disgusted, They could've atleast made some kind of mouse and keyboard support, I feel robbed.

You seriously can't convert the whole game straight from console to PC, what the hell were they thinking?They listened to  us  fans like no other gaming company before, but then failed us by rushing it without making any changes into it, I mean c'mon Lionhead, get your ♥♥♥♥ together..

reviewText:
I must say this game port is a good example of lazy devs making  money off an unfinished game. this game is in need of some serious bug testing (Videocard testing please! dammnit!). The latest update for the game completely broke my game, and it still can't get it to work after hours searching the fable community. reviewText:
I would enjoy the game if it was not from the fact that the game crashes every fourth checkpoint reload. Also, there is no warning when you are low health (at leat in heroic mode) so sometimes you dont even know you are about to die and boom. you have to restart. Oh yeah, if the only sign is the guy that says: you are low health, well before he ends his sentence, you are dead. Never heard of an alarm beep, like in every other game? Or the screen getting red? or a quick heartbeat? Anything? seriously? Also, what's is wrong with the camera? You jam into walls, it spins around at 300mph... And it's cool, you can lock on people. but Instead of targeting the closest enemy, sometimes it targets random people around, or even guys not attacking you, so your back is exposed and you get killed in 0.5 second.

Is there a refund button?

It would be a great game if it was not from the fact that I have to restart the game every 10 minutes. The graphics are great and it brings back a lot of good memories. It could be a better gameplay.

reviewText:
This game is great! At the current price, yes, it is pretty expensive. I bought it at a discount for preorder, and I am not disappointed in my purchase. There are caveats to complete enjoyment like I have encountered.

1, I play this game with a controller (mouse is not supported in the menu)
2. I downscale the game for better visuals (the game is slightly blurry due to DoF)
3. I anticipate modding making the game even better. (this is the real game changer)
4. I try to get my combat multiplier even higher!!! (if you don't try then the game can get really repetitive fast)

I feel this game holds onto something that has been lost in modern games, the idea of evolving characters and enimies seems to be non-existent in todays games. This game was a real treat!

reviewText:
As much as I will still play this game for the sake of replaying an awesome game from when I was in elementary school, I can't recommend it for anyone. If you have a disc of the original game just reinstall that! For me this was worth buying on sale for conveinient access and achievments/ trading cards. If you aren't interested in those things stay away. Check out the original game - http://store.steampowered.com/app/204030/.

My expectations were a remade game, that means a better port that isn't so obviously made for a console like the original and better graphics all around, that means don't just add new textures and leave everything else the same.
Really, if those two things were satisfied I'd be so happy with this rerelease, but they weren't. While visually it's a tad better you still get the same kind of awkward twitching and unemmersive speech from people you saw ten years ago. Those kinds of issues still linger relative to both communication with NPCs and other aspects of the world. Nothing has changed to do with the skill system (which would have brought tears to my eyes if they revamped well) and honestly, everytime I access that menu I'm just reminded how much they did care about the PC port.

In short - Fable is a great game. If you haven't played it and this is on sale for the same price as lost chapters get it for the better textures and new armours. If it isn't on sale, get the original which again is here http://store.steampowered.com/app/204030/. The game is amazing, but this rerelease is not worth a 40 dollar price tag.

Keep an eye on the workshop community. If it gets popular it has the potential to save this game.

voteText: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I cannot believe they ported the xbox game, which ALREADY WAS A PORT FROM THE PC.

It's still your beloved Fable, but the inventory is completely screwed. What's worse, the game does not have mouse integration. This means you will have to click on buttons to navigate the menu, the inventory, your weapons, stuff, basically everything. This is unacceptable and completely cuts the games flow. Its as if the game is trying to stop you from playing it.

As for the graphics and what not, the game looks worse now because the amazing lighting and atmosphere that the first game had is now replaced with darker colours and tons of shadow. This game does not feel like Fable.

Stay away from this. It's an insult that they even dare to ask 35 dollars for this.

EDIT: Now that some time has passed and key remapping has been implemented with patches, I can recommend the game. The inventory is still hard to navigate, but with mapping options it becomes less of a battle and more of an enjoyable thing. And they have fixed the graphics issues as well, which means the game looks sharper and brighter.

reviewText: I love Fable! My brother got me this game based on what I liked as far as the limited knowledge of games I had and preference as far as taste levels go. (I love me some fantasy!) reviewText: Im seeing a lot of negative reviews for this game, however i certainly enjoyed the play through. I've played this game 3 or 4 times when i came out and i was not dis-satisfied in anyway with this purchase. True there was one bug that caused me to have to load to a previous save, but in the 20 hours or so it took me to beat the game i found it to be pretty minor. Dont buy this game if you are expecting drastic changes from the original, i was glad that they kept the core game the same as the original because it was enjoybale on all levels. If you want this game to be a little more challenging then i would play without the revive vials but i just played it for the enjoyment and died maybe once when i was stoned a ♥♥♥♥. Anyways i would reccomend this game especially if you have yet to play any of the fable games, this is by far the best out of the series.

reviewText:
TL;DR Terrible remake, play the original instead.

Where do I even start with this cash grab of a game? I'm a long-time fan of the fable series, played every title since the original pc version of The Lost Chapters (TLC) and absolutely loved most of them but after playing this game I'm not at all surprised Lionhead Studios closed. This game is actually a downgrade from TLC, with the same glitches as the original plus more, the most annoying menu system I’ve ever used and visuals which are still subpar of a modern $35US game.

Contents of disappointment:
-Glitching, bugs and terrible mechanical changes
-Clunky Interface design and control
-Laziest visual upgrades in a remake ever

Glitching, bugs and terrible mechanical changes:
Do like your eardrums, then this game isn’t for you. I found that after playing the game for a while, the audio starts to distort and crackle which only restarting the game fixed. The new checkpoint saves are completely broken. When I checkpoint saved, looted a chest, loaded the save, the chest was still open but the item was gone from my inventory, meaning I lost items that I couldn’t get back without starting over. This new system was meant to fix the hero save exploit but being lazily applied, only managed to break the game. It also has weird fps drops, though I’m using a good computer it still dropped at places no matter what settings it was on.

Clunky interface design and control:
What’s the one advantage of using menus on a PC? Being able to navigate them with the mouse is a good one. This game does not have this function and even worse, it uses keys that are not intuitive in the slightest, using the ins, home, del and end keys to navigate the menu system. I should also mention that TLC, though its menu system was also a little clunky, you could use a mouse to navigate. Also key bindings are a good thing to be able to change depending on your play style but unlike TLC where you can change any of the keys, you can only change a few of them in anniversary.

Laziest visual upgrades in a remake ever:
When you buy a '9 years later' remake of a game, you’d expect visuals that would make your jaw drop when you compare them with each other. Fable Anniversary does not do this, though the textures themselves are of higher resolutions then that of the original, the new textures look out of place and quite weird on the models. They did nothing to the animations and barely anything to the models so most of the characters in the game, they may as well be mutants with how they look. The texture quality is terrible, on max most of the textures are still the quality of the Xbox 360, which is unacceptable for a modern pc game and is not worth the $35. This point is a bit of personal opinion but the non-changeable FXAA makes the game as a whole look way too blurry as well. TLC had amazing graphics for its time and nothing in it has aged enough to be unrecognisable. TLC also supports 16:10 ratios and can be used at 4k.

Fable Anniversary’s little bit of eye candy doesn’t make up for its many downfalls, TLC cost less than 1/3 of its price and is still a much better game then this garbage. TLC still runs on modern operating systems without much hassle, so the remake for PC is just not worth it.

reviewText:
I bought this game as a fan. I have already played it a million times. So, I know I really like it.  I like how my character looks amazing as he progresses.  I also like that this game is about choices and how the world reacts to those choices.  That's what made this game so innovative in it's day.  I really loved this game in it's day. I played it so much I killed my first xbox.  But, as amazing as this game is, I still had my issues with it.

For a game about choices and change. The first one did not give me a choice to be a female. Here I am in playing this amazing game, in this amazing world, kicking butt as the male I have always dreamed to be. Uh no! lol. Sorry, but I want to kick butt as a female thank you.  I wanted to look good in that shiny armor as female.

Then the 2nd one came out. I have the choice to be a female.  But, now the armor sucks cause the the story goes into the future a bit! Still I played because I enjoyed kicking butt and I really enjoyed the rest of the game.  I did like the steam punk twist to things. I really enjoy that.

I still would recommend this game. Because for gaming sake, it is still a fun game to play.

reviewText:
Absolutely terrible.  Not only were the graphics nearly identical in all the environments I have so far experienced, but the small changes they made to important characters were awful.  Maze's hair/tattoos/face is broken, and all spell graphics are either the same or for some reason downgraded in quality.  My hero is uglier than sin, regardless of what type of tattoos, facial hair, or scars I try to apply to him.

The audio is, as far as I can tell, the same.  I have noticed that the natural pauses in conversation that I remember being present in the first game were either shortened or deleted in this game.

The worst part is probably the menu and lack of hero save.  The menu is terrible, clearly ported directly from console, as it does not support the mouse and you must use the 'insert, home, delete, and end' buttons to navigate.  In addition, you cannot re-bind any skills on your mouse  (since as far as the menu is concerned, it does not exist.

Last but not least, there is no hero save.  That means if you're like me and work hard to get very powerful early in the storyline, you'll be age 65 when you meet your *maybe 20's* older sister.  And you'll be old enough to be your own grandfather when you meet your mother.

Awful.

1/10, would not waste time with.

reviewText:
FABLE ANNIVERSARY: DO YOU WANT IT!?
Have you been looking at the new Fable Anniversary relaease, wondering if you should pull the trigger and add that pup to your library? I asked myself the same question almost two months ago when I decided to shoot for the stars with Fable Anniversary. Here I have for you a few words of caution and/or encouragement. My first exposure to the Fable franchise was a few months after the release of the original on the XBOX, I was blown away and drawn back, simultaneously, to the alluring pull of this new, ambitious and anglo-centric adventure. This was like re-living the debut of Ocarina of Time! Fable, however, was of an entirely different realm. Putting much of the focus into the adverse gameplay style and the design of this beautiful reimagining of the British Isles, Fable left a little to be desired of the story. This was remedied with the addition of The Lost Chapters which made the game almost perfect, aside from a few problems that still exist in the new Anniversary version.

Foremost, the game is supposed to be about making choices and becoming your own hero; the game is constantly trying to force you into being the well rounded and skilled player that the game needs you to be which makes certain boss fights or other missions difficult or undoable if your hero build isn't right. For example: Fighting Jack of Blades the first time the game wants you to use a bow. I dont want to use bows with my spellwarrior. I WANNA USE MY MELEE AND SPELLS!!! (fighting the Kracken will also take two hours if you try and use a sword and a lightning spell). This is a major problem with the Anniversary version because it still exists in every facet of playing this game making all of your decisions practically pointless and almost all the time reversable (i.e. you can go from good to evil with relative ease). It was ignorable the first time because all of this was so fresh and never really done like this before. After a decade of making games based on free will and adventure, you should be able to recognise the little problems that make your whole morality matrix and character role development feel a little redundant and pre determined. (i.e in Fable you always end up with A or B, never is a C or D involved) Fable was and is a game which does not require much time to complete the core of it but potentially doubles it's playability when you add in the side missions and all the other quirks of Albion. This was done extremely well especially with the addition of The Lost Chapters. I hoped and expected that with the new release we might get another 9 hours out of this game, but here we find much more to be desired.

Moving on to the NEW issues with Fable Anniversarry, we take a look at what Anniversary does to leave the gamer longing for more, which isn't always a good thing in necessity. No new missions. If you remembered how to play the last game through, you know this one. Some might see this as a good thing, I figure my expectations were too high. But when I learned not even a single new side mission or interactable character was added to the Anniversary version, I was quite dissappointed. So what did they do? Is anything in this new-old game different or improved? Not really, its still the same semi-goofy adventure. Its the same.

The game is the same.

It is the same.

IT'S THE SAME!!!

However you do get a new and slightly longer Heroic mode: There are no ressurection phials and some healing abilities are somewhat gimped. Slightly prolonged eh? HOW IS POSSIBRU IF NO CONTENTS R NU!?!? Well if you never died before whilst playing Fable (this is not uncommon) you probably will die and if you haven't played a Fable game in a couple years like me and decide to jump right in, you may die a lot. All of this dying and reloading is what gives you those extra hours, especially if you're trying to be a good guy (the hardest kinda guy to be). The game is not necessarily more difficult, it just takes longer and sort of forces you to try and gain more experience to level up as you bump along those good ol' core quests. The difficulty in the boss fights comes from getting too bored to actually follow the attack sequences in order to hit the boss amid the 15 minutes of minion fighting/dodging before the 5 seconds you actually get to hit the boss with (assuming you have the right spell, weapon, blood type, zodiac sign, character alignment, age etc.) Here is the attack sequence for every major boss in the game *SPOILER ALERT*:

DODGE, KILL MINIONS, DODGE, KILL MINIONS, DODGE, HIT THE BOSS (with the one and only attack), FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, RELOAD, DODGE, FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, RELOAD, BEGIN ARHYTHMICALLY POUNDING KEYS/BUTTONS *with specifically designated spells/weapons for that boss* PROFIT!?

It isn't even subtle the way the game trys to force you into being what it needs you to be rather than what you want to play with. If you have the same sense of conquest and need of self reassurance that I had when I started off, I would reccomend doing the heroic mode first to get it out of the way in order to enjoy the far and few between favorable little pieces that have been reworked in Anniversary.

The controls cannot be criticized too heavily as Lionhead was sort of venturing into new territory with operating systems being different these days on the PC, as well as two different controller formats, a total of three control types to be programmed and supported. I'm no expert but that probably sounds easier in type than it is in reality. I use a 360 controller, which can be tricky but you will get used to it and once you do it's almost like the good old days. So, have I gotten older, more mature or more jaded in the decade between the original and the anniversary. Yes I'd guess so.

SO TO ANYONE NEW TO THE FABLE FRANCHISE, MEANING YOU'VE NEVER PLAYED FABLE BEFORE; THIS GAME IS FOR YOU! BUY IT TO SUPPORT LIONHEAD AND FUTURE VENTURES![/b]

Words of warning; if you're a fan like me, you will most likely find more to complain about. But I'm no Negative Nancy. The second you step into Albion it is beautiful. The updated graphics are what I wanted, not too pristine but volumes more detail than the original. The integrity of the art is indeed intact. The new outfits, weapons and armor are also a great leg up in the game because you finally get more sets that can be more specific, even more condusive to building the kind of character you want to play...Assuming it still fits the Lionhead template. There is no damage done to the story, interactions with characters or any of the little running jokes and insider quirks we all adore hidden about the game. Would I have been willing to relenquish some of the humor or parts of the story in order to make way for new grounds in exploration of the map or exploration of different characters and I dunno, maybe a new mission or two? Definitely. Perhaps the most important and beneficial aspect that Lionhead added to the release of Anniversary was the ability for the community to create their own mods to the Fable program. I am very excited to see what the more skilled enthusiasts will creeate. Keep in mind this is all being written around/about the game that I wanted. Something slightly newer, something a little more in depth, something with a twist and above all something with a little more to explore. Some might say that what I wanted was a new game. In some ways, some people are right. But if you want something a little redundant, a little repetative, a little fickle, a little quirky and/or a little nostalgic, maybe even a little new; Look no further than Fable Anniversary...or this review


Remember friends, keep your expectations and your promises low, but over-deliver with every opportunity.

reviewText:
This remaster is very well done and while it does have some issues, is still very enjoyable. Fable: TLC is my favorite game of all time and this version is a welcome addition to my collection and one that I will be spending a lot of time with. I have had no problems running this game, no crashes, no stutters, no blur problems that others have had and I don't really have the best setup.

Now there are two issues that I have with this game, but they do not make the game unplayable.

The first issue is that there is only partial Mouse Support. You cannot use the mouse at all in the menus and the developers chose some convoluted keys to navigate the menus that are difficult to use, especially on a laptop. The keys that you use to navigate are A"

reviewText:
Fable Anniversary is a nice remake of The Lost Chapters.When this game released it had too many bugs and all people said , that it's a very bad remake like a sh-it ,creators listened them and they have fixed these bugs.After this fix the game became a really nice RPG , but nothing don't compare with original game.
There are no many distinctions between anniversary and the lost chapters , only graphics(but it isn't very nice)  and soundtrack(it's a really nice music in the game).I bought this game because it's nostalgia for me and I really like the Fable's serie.I played all parts of this game and all of them have pleased me.If you very like this game , you can buy this game and support  creators and they will release a new part.Some pluses and minuses of this game:
+Not bad graphics
+Cheap game
+Nice gameplay
+Wonderfull storyline
+Good soundtrack
+Xbox controller support
+Steam Achievements
+When you will finish story , you can travel the game's world and do some things,which you want
And a little more.
-Bad voice acting.
-I pre-bought this game and I didn't take all DLC , although creators said that I can take all of them.
I  recommend this game for people , which like nice RPG games.Don't spare money , just buy this game!

reviewText:
I really just can't recommend this game. The original is just so much more better.

Pros:

Better graphics.
Better sound quality.

Cons:

Attacking delays.
Frequent crashes.
Audio skipping in cinematic scenes.
Low FPS. (I was aware with remastered graphics it would take more, but I would've never guessed by this much)
Bugs as far as the eye can see.
Random, and annoying freezes.
and the most annoying one of all... After completing an attack combo your character will stay frozen for who knows how long. I refunded the game before he ever un-froze.

So to sum it all up, Fable: Anniversary is a complete mess, and was too lazily done, and still requires a ton of patching up. If you want to buy this game, buy the original here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/204030 Worse graphics, but at least the game is playable, and is still a whole load of fun.

I give Fable: Anniversary a 2/10

reviewText:
If you're looking for a PC game, stick with the original version. NOTE: A patch has been released relaxing the restrictions on keybinds. Regardless, I am leaving this review as it is to depict the intial release and because I still fully support the summary.

Let me try to paint a picture of my experience with this game.

I started out using a mouse and keyboard, huge mistake. For those who did not know, this very same game was released 10 years ago on PC, mouse and keyboard was the only option to play it. The original offered full customization of the control setup and allowed the use of a cursor to go through several of the menus.

For that reason, it was to my surprise to find out that, not only was the mouse not usable in any of the menus in this game, but it had been replaced with the arrow keys and the A and B buttons. This in itself was pretty jarring, although, if this had only been an issue with the pre-game menu, it would not have been as severe an issue. Instead, EVERY SINGLE MENU uses this control scheme. Fable is an RPG, it requires a lot of menu crawling, to have to use these asinine controls, every single time I need to select something, it wears pretty thin.

Now, whatever, at least the mouse works ingame, right? Only partially. I glided through the Oakvale segment with little to no issue, but quickly found myself bumping into another wall. What would that be? The block tutorial. Blocking, like all commands that utilize the mouse, are unable to be binded to a different key (even though this was possible 10 years ago). Because of this, if you do not have the capability to use the middle mouse button, you're screwed.

After accepting that this updated" game was in no way built to use a mouse and keyboard. I switched to a controller. Unfortunately

reviewText:
Fable: The Lost Chapters was my first Fable game and the only one that really sticks out of all the others, but this Anniversary is a joke.

Lionhead Studios/Microsoft didn't bother to add new voiceovers or overall sounds. The gameplay is just the same clunky like in Fable:TLC, nothing has been touched there, except for the controller option. And probably the worst, NO NEW QUEST? NOTHING AT ALL?! I was hoping for a sandbox mode with new quest and maybe activities once I completed the game. but there's nothing!  Just your daily Fable life with your imaginary wife and sometimes helping out a wandering trader. The guildmaster also became silent and no one has something to say that I saved their life from Dragon Jack.

Improved graphics doesn't make an Anniversary game Lionhead Studios/Microsoft, especially if they aren't that good. And how can it even be that an Anniversary release has less options than the 10 year older original game?

This said, I had my share fun with the game. The nostalgia was big walking through Albion. I still don't suggest anyone to buy this version of the game. Go get yourself Fable: TLC which is just the same and cheaper! Atleast I bought this game via a thirdpartysite.

reviewText:
Yikes! This game is unfinished and nearly unplayable.
Apart from the poor menu system, and the general difficulty is reassigning keys, the framerate is poor, doesn't look HD, and the camera jerks all over the place if using a mouse. Anyone who has motion sickness, you may actually vomit.
It is obviously made for using an Xbox controller, but this is a PC game. Why a controller? Why not have mouse function in menus for an RPG game that's all about customisation?
I hope a quality patch fixes these issues, the game seems like a rushed port and many will be feeling the burn from forking out good money for a barely functioning game.

In the end, I'm sure if Lionhead came out and said 'we need on more month to make it perfect' I'm sure everyone would understand. To release it as it currently is, well that's just unprofessional and a stab in the heart of the diehard fans who were hanging out for this game.

WIll cross my fingers for a patch, as I know there's no chance of a refund.

What a shame...

reviewText:
Fable was one of the original games that allowed you to decide who you wanted to be. It was a very popular game for that reason. Fable 1, TLC and Anniversary will always be better than Fable 2 and Fable 3. Not that I didn't enjoy those games either. It's nearly impossible to see sequels or anything further, best the first and original game. With a large community that has loved and cherished this game through the years; there can be a LOT of mods and new content on the approach. Not sure what happened with the Custom Tattoo feature that was previously in The Lost Chapters.

I'm sure that most of you, if not all, have beaten the story line at least once. The story line was superb and I will pretty much leave it at that. You must see the story for yourself, since there are multiple ways of gameplay.

The new updated graphics are very appealing. Runs a lot smoother than TLC and deifnitely the original. They had fixed some glitches from the previous versions and they have also developed new ones that are currently being addressed. I've been enjoying this game like I have when I first got it. It has a lot of replay value.

If you are new to RPGS, I would definitely recommend this game to you for a starter.

5/5

reviewText:
Hey guys,


I've been playing this game for a while. In my own opinion, it is one of the great games, as I never got to play the original Fable:TLC as a kid. Objectively, the gameplay is the same as original, as I have watched the TLC's videos on youtube. It doesn't deviate in anyway.

Pros:
- Same gameplay controls as original (From what I've seen in youtube for TLC)
- Their UI is different to the original (In my opinion, that's pleasin' to my eyes compared to the original)
- Their graphics differ greatly, as they use Unreal Engine. Anniversary has more colours, shadows and details
- It is moddable
- It does have ALL TLC's DLCS included in it.
- They did add new equipment to this game such as  Snowspire Guard Outfit and the Jackarse
- It has the new difficulty that makes this game a bit challenging
Con:
- For anyone that have played TLC, they won't see any differences in it.
- No mouse support in the menu and inventory.

TL;DR - Worth getting it if you want to relive nostalgia in a new skin, or you never had a chance to play the original Fable in my opinion. You may not find it any different to original Fable, just loaded with a bit of new equipment, that's all.

reviewText: It seems like a lot of people who have reviewed this game poorly either played the game before the implementation of the newest patches or were expecting the game to be on the visual level of fable III. This game is an HD remaster of a 10 year old game, so of course it's not going to look quite as good. Having said that, I still think it looks great. If you already own the original version of the game and are still content with it, then it probably isn't worth it for you to buy the anniversary edition. However, if you have never played fable before and are looking to get into it (or you just don't have it on steam) then I'd highly recommend spending the extra cash for the anniversary edition.\n\nExcellent combat system, captivating storyline, and this is one of the few games that make me feel like my decisions have an impact. 10/10

reviewText: I loved Fable on XBOX and each of the sequels - that's what it's incredibly upsetting that Fable Anniversary is so choppy that it's nearly unplayable. I'm playing on an HP Pavillion Laptop with an AMD A10 2.10 GHz processor and 8 GB of RAM - which should be able to handle the game. Instead I'm spending my first few hours playing around with settings to try to get my character to not pause for a frame between every step he takes. The cut scenes look terrible too - the sun rising took a quick break halfway up due to this choppiness - and the character interactions look worse than on the original XBOX version. I'm going to keep looking online for ways to improve the performance but 1 hour into the game it's pretty clear that Lionhead didn't put much effort into this. Thanks for the huge dissapointment :(\n\nUpdate - I ended up playing through the main story and mostly ingnoring the bugginess. The choppiness gets better after the Hero Guild Graduation - but not completely. I used the Slow Time spell to make the lagginess seem less out of place, and tended to skip all the cutscenes. I did put in a lot of hours, and did enjoy myself, but if I had a choice to go back and buy this again I wouldn't. I'd take a train out to my mother's house in the subburbs and plug in my old XBOX and play the original instead.

reviewText:
Here's the problem with Fable Anniversary: if you don't reeeally love Fable, there is literally no point in getting this. Unless of course you like acheivments and trading cards.

But do I love Fable Anniversary? Nope. Do I love Fable? Yep. Will anybody new to Fable love this game? Probably not.
Which is why I really would struggle to recommend it to anybody who doesn't already like fable. And you'd probably really (I meant REALLY) have to like Fable to get the most out of this.

reviewText: Fable Aniversary is a remake of Fable the Lost Chapers. One of my all time favorite games. While the game stays true to the original, I felt as though it could have been expanded upon. For instance, a gender option or perhaps new spells and demon doors. Also since it's a remake there should be an option to switch back and forth to see what the game looked like ten or eleven years ago. From what I can tell a controller is pretty much the way to go with this game much like the original. Everyone seems to be complaining about the graphics but to me they look fine. All in all it's a very faithful remake with some minor flaws and missed oppertunities. I'd give it a 7/10. If you're a new fan playing this then things may be a little confusing for you but as things get going, you get the hang of it. Highly would reccomend for any returning fan
