reviewText:
Basing my review off the original that I played on the Xbox and also on Steam.

Pros:
Lovely graphics. I originally thought they wouldn't be great but they're a fantastic addition.
Not much has changed from the original game in a good way. All the core mechanics such as spells, quirky one liners, spells and everything in between that made the great game is still present.
Mod support. As of now (01/01/2015) there isn't much besides aesthetic improvements, but the community will continue to grow and I believe it will add a lot to the game once people add their creative insight.
Cons:
They changed around the UI for the menu/item screen which made it worse, especially for the PC users. A lot of the navigation which was perfect in the original has become clunky and a hindrance.
Controls still feel like they're targeted more for console users even after changing a lot of the key bindings.
Overpriced in my opinion. Try and get the game on sale. It shouldn't be priced more than $20.
Overall, I would recommend getting the game as it is a fond reminder for those that have played the original as well a great experience for new comers. I would highly recommend getting the game on sale and not to purchase it at full price.

reviewText:
I wrote a 1300 word review of this game which apparently surpasses steam's capacity for reviews. So, with much reluctance I present to you the dot-point summary of my masterfully fleshed out glorious review of Fable: Anniversary; an HD Modern Re-Release of Fable: The Lost Chapters;

The Good
- Expansive world which reacts to your decisions rather nicely
- Visuals can be quite pretty in places (animations and models a bit uglier in other spots though)
- Quick travel, mechanics and controls are quite good (set to classic. Seriously.)
- Quests are varied, fun, and challenging when you 'boast'.
- Humour is highly appreciated and nicely balances against the grittier elements of this game.
- Play it in a bunch of ways, you'll probably be a mix of good and evil but tofu your way to goodness if you're like me.

The Less Than Good
- Bugs. Here and there. Can be rather annoying
- Audio is too compressed for my liking
- No female character available, your control over how they look is both expansive but also limited (e.g. hair colour)
- Aging can be ridiculously fast. Its cool, but like, chill.
- Some aspects of the game which would be fun (stealing) are hugely difficult.

Fable: Anniversary is a game which has a wonderful soundtrack, excellent balance of darker elements with some tongue-in-cheek humour intersperced throughout, wonderful character-world interaction and an excellent quest and navigational system. It's held back by some distressing bugs and poor audio quality at times, but otherwise is a great romp into a classic RPG.

8/10

reviewText: Fable: TLC is possibly the best action RPG ever produced. The atomosphere is sublime, the combat is fast and diverse, and the music is incredible. Some people will argue against paying the $35 for the updated version, but I disagree. The graphics are much better than TLC, and it's overall just a better experience with support for higher resolutions and widescreen. The only pitfall with this version is the new menu system, which is obviously designed for play with a controller.  Overall, it's a great RPG with tons of replayability and a fantastic atmosphere unmatched by many games since.\n\n[EDIT: There's been a patch that disables weather effects in one of the areas near the middle of the game. Until this is fixed, which it hopefully will be, keep that in mind before purchasing the game.]

reviewText:
Great game, I have played both Anniversary and TLC.

Fable I has a great storyline and is totally worth the money. It has a few bugs tho.
TLC is great for the oldschool feels if you have played it before, if you haven't played it ever dont worry graphics and sound are pretty good for the release date.

Now what should you pick, TLC or Anniversary?
- Anniversary has controller support, mods (not alot) and updated graphics. So if you love your controller and/or have never played TLC and have the money I would recommend you Anniversary

- For the oldschool players around: I recommend buying TLC, you are gonne have them oldschool feels... Anniversary has some differences from TLC you might find annoying, like different faces on your favourite characters, mobs spawning in later than usual, etc.  - You can find TLC  here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/204030/

Anyway, good luck and have fun in Albion

reviewText:
For those of you who may have played Fable II and Fable III and liked those, but never got to experience this original game, I would highly recommend this game. I will say that $35 is a bit steep for a graphical overhaul, as most of the mechanics (as far as I can tell) haven't been altered. For first timers it might be worth it, but if it goes on sale for 25% or more I would definitely recommend picking it up.

For those that have played/own the original version, the $35 price tag is way overpriced. I would recommend waiting for at least a 50% off sale before picking this up.

Bottom line... I picked this game up after get one of the mass distributed coupons for 60% off and I jumped on the offer, and I say it was well worth it. The graphics are beautiful to look at. Nothing revolutionary or next gen, but a great enough improvement over the original that makes playing through it again a whole new experience.

As for the few things I dont like...
- If playing with a controller... Even though I have been using 360 controllers since '06 I still find myself attempting to hit those Black/White buttons to use my bow and sword, but those are now assigned to the LB and RB. There is an option for a more Fable II and III control scheme, where X is melee, and Y is the bow. I like that control setup more, overall, but it messes with my instinct to push Y to block like the original controls do.

-The faces are the one thing that seem to have suffered in the overhaul. The Hero's, Maze, and the Guildmasters faces all look wrong, compared to what I expected from the original game. But it is easily able to be overlooked and ignored.

The things I have mixed feelings on...
- The new menu interface... It is very different from the original. If this is your first time playing the game, dont worry. The menu setup is still logical, just different. lol It definitely looks nicer, I am just still adjusting to using the LB/RB and LT/RT to navigate rather than just having a list you scroll through with the thumbstick.

- The difficulty... I recall that during my first one or two playthroughs of the game on Xbox, I used many Ressurection Phials. And then I got to the point where I could sell all but one or two, as I very rarely needed them. The Anniversary edition has two difficulties (the original just had one IIRC), the classic difficulty, and a harder one. I seriously debated playing the harder one right off the bat, as I remember that I had stopped playing the original in part because it felt too easy. But now... maybe the default is harder, or more likely I just lost my edge" in the game from not playing it for a long time. I have only played about 4 hours I think at the time of writing this
date:
and I have already used 4 or 5 Phials. lol

The things I like...
- The graphics
recommended: obviously. I like seeing the detail on my gear now
hoursPlayed: and the world seems more vibrant. I have enjoyed just running around and looking at things.\n\n- Even though it seems I would have been committing suicide
voteText: I am glad that there is a harder difficulty for when I am ready to attempt that.\n\n- It is the same game I fell in love with so many years ago. Yes
helpfulPercent: including bugs lol. They had debated redoing the entire game
votesHelpful: but I am glad they didnt. It would have been nice to see the bugs fixed
votesTotal: but there arent even enough to be concerned about really. This game gives me a rather large sense of visually updated nostalgia. Aside from the Halo games on Xbox
votesFunny: this game was my next favorite."

reviewText:
I do not care how well a sculpter can carve an ice statue if they will only do so in hell. It will melt before anyone can enjoy it.

If you are going to remake a game, you should try to improve areas that need improving while not destroying areas that are fine(such as the camera). And if you are going to make a game for PC, step one is to allow your paying customer the ability to change keybindings.

A game that will not let me control my character in the way that I would like OR let me see the surroundings I like? An Ice swan in hell.

I regret paying for this game, this studio has disappointed me for the last time.

reviewText: Fable 1 is like dollar store candy- cheap and unsophisticated, but still tasty none-the-less in a junky kind of way. It helps that it doesn't take itself seriously in the least. Anniversary, then, is like the candy makers going over the recipe again, fiddling with the sugar quantity, maybe sourcing a slightly better supplier of chocolate liquer, upgrading their factory machinery, and investing in a more professional-looking packaging. Its still junky dollar-store candy, but now its the BEST junky dollar-store candy. Patching has done much to resolve stability issues, and my gripes are few, mostly in relation to non-functionality of Boast UI and the continued annoyance of trying to buy property in Bowerstone South.

reviewText: Fable was a game backed by huge promises and a lot of hype. Although it didn't live up to every claim that Lionhead Studios made, it did manage to deliver a great action RPG, with a lot of character and humour. Fable Anniversary on Xbox 360 gave me so many problems, that it left a sour taste in my mouth, and I flat out put that console back in the closet. I found it on here for sale the other day, and I am glad I gave this one a second shot. I got to relive all the epic moments and see all the sights Albion has to offer, but this time with a fresh coat of paint and a few slight changes to bring this game up to par. Aside from a few problems here and there (nothing game breaking) and some freaky looking character models, Fable Anniversary was 20 hours well spent, and I actually look forward to my next adventure in this wonderful game!

reviewText:
Where to begin,

Let me start off by saying the original Fable game was one of my first Microsoft gaming experiences (Got it with the Crystal EDition Xbox with Fable and Crimson Skies). Since then however many years ago, Ive owned 6 copies of this game whether it be the original, lost chapters, or anniversary. It was on sale on the summer sale and for the low price tag, I had to try the PC port.

Im a huge fan of the game, and the series, however this PC port is less than what is desired. Lets start off with the basic skeleton of the game, the graphics.

Graphics

This Anniversary edition is pretty much Lost Chapters remastered, with a very linear reskin for graphics. The graphics have improved by a little bit yes, but some animations are still quite static and robotic. For a game they are asking $40 full price I guess there isnt too much space to complain about, but when you look at other aanniversary games (Halo 2 Anniversary as an example) that offer full redone and appropriate next gen reskin, its hard to pass this as acceptable. For owners of Lost chapters, its not worth spending that kind of money for minor graphical enhancements. The thing with graphics that drive me nuts with this game is the color palette and shadowing. Original fans like myself will notice this when you first start off, as the green and red outlines around foes/allies are a murky and dull shade, where these colors should be vibrant and identifiable such as the original.
Id give the graphics 3/5.

Sound

For me this games sound component has always been stellar. The composed music in this game is well written and very recognizable. The music composure fits the game well, and changes appropriately without being abrupt as situations in the game change. Whether its browsing throughout the guild, to entering the woods and entering into a combat scenario. As far as sound effects go there is quite abit of repitition, but its to be expected in an older title, and its only going to bug you if you focus on it. Voice acting is another strong point of this game as some of the main characters (minus your hero obviously!) have very interesting voices, and some of the scripting the speak is quite funny and entertaining.
Overall, with the music being a strong point for me and the mix of it all into one works well, id give the sound 4.25/5, especially considering the age of the game (unsure if sound was remastered for the anniversary edition, will have to look)

Story

Another great part of this game. Original fans will feel quite at home and know what they are getting into. New fans will have a great story mode to get into and see how it all intertwines. From the original Oakvale raid, to the battle with Jack of blades, its quite a nice vengeance based story mode that will keep you interested. The transition from the original game to the added extention of Lost Chapters has always been odd for me. You can definitly tell where the original game ended, and where they slapped on the added part of TLC. However, the variety in missions and rewards make this well worth looking into. 4/5

Controls

Here is the major flaw with this PC port. The controls are awful. Controlling the camera with the mouse while trying to balance out everything else out on the keyboard is less than desired. In High tempo, higher ranked combat it is quite difficult to go from say a range attack, to melee, to will in a smooth way. I find myself getting lost on the keyboard trying to remember all the silly Hotkeys (Clicking in the mouse wheel to block?!). I havent looked to see if I can change these or not, but even fresh off the install, better controls should be offered as you seem to be all over the keyboard to map simple combos and interactions. Again im very new to the PC port, so I dont consider this part of the review to be fair. Im going to look into other control options, and test out the full control compatibility and update this.
But as of now, 2/5 for controls

Gameplay

Being a fan of this game I knew what I was getting into. There are gold quests which are your main storyline quests, while silver are selective. Theres a great balance between these quests and none of the main quests seem repititous in anyway. They are all interconnected and feel smooth, while the silver quests seem to be less polished. Whether its combat in the Arena Quest, or racing in your underwear in the prison, I think most gamers will be quite happy with the versatility offered in this game. Its nowhere near as in depth as other RPGs as Skyrim or WoW, but for a casual common gamer such as myself that doesnt want to put 500hrs into the game, its great for pickup and play.
The combat mechanics are simple, yet effective. You have a decent selection of basic weapons (Swords, Hammers, Scythes, Bows, Crossbows, etc) which are then placed into damage categories based on level (Obsidian, Master etc). Not to mention the Legendary weapons you can find in game through chests, quests, and other means. Like previously stated, the only amjor hinderance with the combat in this game is abmysal controls.
Gameplay 4.25/5

Overall, would I recommend this game? For the $9 I paid for it, definitly. For users looking to get into it I cannot recommend it at $40. Owners of Lost Chapters especially, save your time and money,

ID RATE THIS PORT 3.5/5

Its a great game for a great series, and those who didnt experience it on both xboxs like I did, I would recommned picking up this port and checking out this great story and game. For myself, I can look  past the flaws as im a huge fan of the game, and hopefully you will do the same and experience the core of Fable and where its popularity came from.

*Thanks for reading my first review, I will update as I continue on with the game as obviously I dont have much time played right now.

reviewText: Fable 1 is like dollar store candy- cheap and unsophisticated, but still tasty none-the-less in a junky kind of way. It helps that it doesn't take itself seriously in the least. Anniversary, then, is like the candy makers going over the recipe again, fiddling with the sugar quantity, maybe sourcing a slightly better supplier of chocolate liquer, upgrading their factory machinery, and investing in a more professional-looking packaging. Its still junky dollar-store candy, but now its the BEST junky dollar-store candy. Patching has done much to resolve stability issues, and my gripes are few, mostly in relation to non-functionality of Boast UI and the continued annoyance of trying to buy property in Bowerstone South.

reviewText:
This is more a remaster than a remake of Fable. Nonetheless, this is probably one of the greatest RPG's ever to have existed so it makes sense to remaster it to preserve it for upcoming generations.

What is Fable? Fable is a game about the life of your in-game character. You will follow him from childhood to his elder years (age is simulated through playtime rather than story). Your decisions shape your character's appearance, reputation and social standing. The way people react to you differs depending on your in-game actions. Did you raid a farm in order to gain some gold, or did you defend it from bandits?

Fable is a game filled with lore and really gives you a good sense of growth. You will feel yourself and your character improve with gameplay. Fighting often with swords makes your character's muscles grow. Eating too much food will make him fat. Using a lot of magic will create rune lines on his skin. Doing good deeds will make your skin lighter and your eyes glow blue. Doing evil deeds will make your skin darker and your eyes glow red. Whatever your decisions, you can bet that the game will reflect it.

I will not spoil anything, but this is one of the greatest RPG stories because of how varied it is. It really feels like you've lived a lifetime by the end of the game; the game feels that lengthy.

The combat is enjoyable as it is a hack n' slash game. This version gives you a 'heroic' mode which really ups the challenge. More tactics is required in heroic mode as you need to plan before heading into battle, which enemies do I kill first
recommended: how should I initially attack". One false move and you will die (and die for good as you will need to restart from a checkpoint).\n\nIf you've already played the game and are purchasing this for the upgraded graphics
hoursPlayed: then you're reading the right review. The graphics are a great improvement. However
voteText: I feel like the game 'feels' different with the new graphics. It feels more like 'clay' rather than the old World of Warcrafty graphics. Hard to describe unless you've played it yourself. In terms of gameplay
helpfulPercent: NOTHING was changed. Everything is the same; the bugs
votesHelpful: the sounds
votesTotal: the interface. They have 'improved' the HUD (which isn't necessarily an improvement
votesFunny: just a reskin).\n\nAll in all
commentsCount: it's a solid remaster but not worth the $40.00 price tag. Wait for a sale; $20 and below and this remaster is definately worth it.\n\nThis remaster gets an 8/10. It lost 2 points due to no improvements/innovation."

reviewText: I couldn't wait to play this game when I heard they were going to remaster it. Fans have been asking them to do an HD remake for years. The gameplay is exactly how it was on the original game (animations and all) and the only thing changed are the graphics. A lot of the reviews are negative for this reason but the majority of the people who were asking for the remake to happen did not and still don't want the original gameplay changed. Yes, there have been some features in Fable 2 and 3 that would have been nice to have on the remake (better animations once again), but a lot of fans, myself included, wanted to play this game exactly as it was. We just wanted to see this great RPG in full HD glory and updated so it ran better, so if you were a fan of the original but wanted improvements on top of the HD remaster, this probably isn't the game for you to buy, but if you, like me, just wanted to see this game in stunning HD quality, this is a great game to buy.\n\nThe only con I have is the new inventory menu. It takes some getting used to and I'd have prefered the original one, but oh well.

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed Fable when it first debuted on the original Xbox. Gameplay feels somewhat outdated although it still fits with the game. reviewText:
Fable is one of my favorit RPG games, and as Fable Anniversary is a remake of the very first one, there is little to say about the actual gameplay. It still as good as when it first came out.

I have tried playing this game with both keyboard and a controller. And I must say it's absolutely horrible to even try to figure out how to play it with the keyboard. The game comes with two setting for the controller, either the classicial one for Fable 1 or the enhanced version that are used in Fable II & III, depending on which control scheme you prefer.

The menus are re-designed and I'm sorry to say that it's to the worse. It's hard to navigate and you never really know where to find anything. You end up spending far too much time on browsing the menu than finding what you are looking for.

The graphics are indeed updated. One can question though if it's really as good as it can be. You still see the low poly and low ress textures. The alpha shaders (hair and vegetations) are beyond all criticism. It's just horrible.

That said, the game is still enjoyable and if you see it only as a slightly enchaed version of the first game, it's still as fun as it was back then.

Graphics 4/10
Gameplay 9/10

reviewText:
Many felt cheated. Well the benefit of steam is: you get discounts....lots of them over every single month. So just wait out till price drops.

I expected nothing more than was it used to be. Considering that most so called HD remake tend to slightly improve the game, I had little to no expectations regarding improved graphics, sound, control, and contents. It's still a solid good ol' rpg.

If you played fable before: Wait for price drop. Unless of course you can ignore the aforementioned lack of 'improvements', then by all means, buy and experience it again. This time with achievements!

If you haven't played fable: Buy it, but don't expect it to be like fable 2 or 3 in terms of contents or graphics. Still the best fable out of all 3 I think.

Or you can simply wait until price drops.

reviewText:
After updates:

Works better now, they've added mouse support. There's still no excuse for it not being in the game at launch, and this IS just an HD remake of a game you can get for less then $10, so I wouldn't recommend purchasing it for the full price but if you can get it on a significant Steam sale for <=$20 I'd highly recommend it if you enjoyed the original (or if you haven't played it but really like RPGs). I have had a lot of fun with it and the fact that it's on Unreal Engine alleviated some of the issues I had with the original on newer OSes such as Windows 8.1.

reviewText:
Updated 10.11.14
So we finally got mouse support, reason to check all patches and take another look at controls, keys and graphics.

The game improved, navigating the menu with the mouse is behaving strange, but thats not unusual for console ports, and at least we can do that now.
So that works argueable well, in comparision with the 4-key system from before its a 400% improvement. The menu was the main reason i didnt play Anniversary so far, it just made the task of doing anything in the menu unbearable. Thats fixed now. It could be better, but its ok.

Contols and fighting system are still like the original, i like that. Yet we werent able to fe. use special mouse buttons or rebind individual actions. All this is possible by now.

Graphics had to live through some changes and are now less blurry and sharper overall. Nice to actually see the better graphics now ;)

For a review of the game itself (story, world gameplay) check my Fable - The Lost Chapters review, the games are 99% identical and control the same way (aside from menu as discussed before).
I'll just say that the old version was/is one of my most favorite games of all time.
http://steamcommunity.com/id/st0l3nid/recommended/204030

Fable Anniversary finally got the curve, there is still some room for improvement, but we can finally enjoy with mouse and keyboard and nice graphics. I change my vot from no to yes therefore.
'nuff said.

reviewText:
The original game with some graphical textures is arguably a much better game overall. The lack of menu and key binding options, the lack of hotkey porting especially (there's no F key bindings I have found), makes this game not only lazy but extremely frustrating to play.

Don't buy this if you are thinking about it. If you haven't seen already, you can't actually use your mouse in the menus. WHY? I assume it would have taken 2 or 3 hours at the very worst to put the capability back in, or copy and adapt the code from *any* other game from the studio.

Edit: 2 months of fixes later and it has become quite a good game, happy to recommend it now.

reviewText:
Pros:
-Solid remake of the original with updated graphics
-Fun, whimsical atmosphere
-Variety of weapons and armor sets to suit your character
-Great amount of content
-Fantastic story
-Morality system that reflects your choices well
-Modding support

Cons:
-No additional content in the remake
-DLCs are overpriced and only offer armor and weapons
-Very occasional graphics issues (her eyeball was clipping through the side of her head!)
-Same old camera angle/clunky control frustrations
-Fable: The Lost Chapters is available for $9.99 and is the exact same game, minus the graphics upgrade and mod support

Overall: This is the original Fable game.  If you haven't played it, it's fantastic, and worth the price.  Whimsical humor and deep gameplay make it a fun RPG.  Choices matter and change the way the world reacts to you.  There are several approaches to combat.  The voice acting is good.  The controls get a bit clunky no matter what version you have, but it's a small flaw in a large gem.  If you can get it on sale, great, or you can pay the cheaper price for the older version as it is the same game.

Bottom Line: At full price, you should probably get Fable: The Lost Chapters, but this is still worth it even paying full price, as it stands on its own.  Get it on sale for the mod support and updated graphics, and support these types of projects!

Yes. Get this version. Full, native controller support is the only real selling point of this over vanilla Lost Chapters, but it's a damn good one.

reviewText:
Fable is what I would call a fantasy classic: You, the protagonist, suffer hardship at a young age, and then learn the skills required to be a Hero (quite literally) and save the world. I have always loved the combat system of Fable and Fable: The Lost Chapters. It feels smooth, and is easy to master. Enemies are always going to be challenging and willing to punish you if you let your guard down. The Fable Series has long been one of my favorite, and I love this remake.

However, there are a few flaws to this. Firstly (and the biggest problem) is the menu. Occasionally the menu will glitch out and either randomly start scrolling through whatever screen you are on, or it will try to prevent you from scrolling through it, constantly dragging your selector (is that even the term?) back to the top of the menu. The second flaw to Fable: Anniversary is the colors. The origional Fable and Fable: The Lost Chapters were these brightly colored places that captured your imagination. Now, the world feels dull and somewhat bland. However, the balance of the coloring it still good, and you won't be bored looking at the world after an hour.

That all being said, I would wholeheartedly recommend this game to everyone, both those who have played the series since the first installments, and new players who found a sale going on.

reviewText:
// RATIONALE FOR PURCHASE AND WHERE I'M COMING FROM //:   I played the original Fable to death on the original xbox.

I played Fable: The Lost Chapters to death on my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ old lappy from 2000 in my adolescence.

I picked this up for the summer sale price of $8 USD.

Didn't see this product at launch and it may have been quite buggy.

Stayed away for a while as I felt my copy of TLC is all I needed, but the sale price seemed worth it at the time as replaying TLC with the dated visuals wasn't as appealing with this existing.   // EXPERIENCE //:  Nothing more than a HD remake of the TLC game in the Unreal Engine, but thats not bad by any means, just worth noting.

Visuals are ok, but the animations for the most part have seem to have been reused, with only facial animations having a minor overhaul. The other animations sometimes clip through some armour sets and it detracts from what they are trying to achieve.

Having played it recently, the game is reasonably stable, with a few very, very minor bugs.

It plays very similar, if not identically to TLC.

It mostly lives up to expectations and its quite enjoyable, but doesn't provide any new content above what was included in TLC. Some find that infuriating, I don't personally. However, I would welcome new content in the same vein as the original titles.   // BOTTOM LINE VERDICT //:   The remake is  worth a sale price value (e.g $8 USD)  ,   NOT    its current full asking price.

If you've played TLC through and through, then the value of buying this is just updated visuals and I recommend  buying it at a low sale price if you really want it.

If you haven't played TLC or Any Fable games, this remake will do the series as much justice as TLC, so the value to a consumer in this category is vast in comparison, however I still only recommend purchasing at sale price as I feel purely updated visuals isn't enough to merit the full price.

reviewText:
Positives:

+ It's Fable; a joyous British action-RPG made with love
+ Gameplay still holds up as an enjoyable romp through Albion
+ Graphics update keeps it relevant and playable on modern machines
+ If you haven't played the original Fable it's the definitive version to play

Negatives:

- Nothing done with the original loading screens and area sizes.  They aren't long however do interrupt gameplay
- Facial animation and features haven't been updated; look very dated and altogether jarring
- UI was slightly fiddly and unmanageable
- If you've already played Fable / Fable: The Lost Chapters there's no real reason to play this

reviewText: Fable: The Lost Chapters has long been my all-time favorite game, one I could always come back to no matter how often and still have a lot of fun and find new things. So when one day I logged onto steam and I was given a coupon for I think it was 75% off of Fable Anniversary, the reboot of Fable: The Lost Chapters with HD and more extras, well how could I have said no? The day I installed Fable Anniversary and jumped right into the story, a wave of sentimental memories as well as newly influenced wonder washed over me. It was the same game that crafted my childhood, yet it was a whole new experience. The controls were almost exactly the same, the major differences being what buttons bring up menus, inventory, etc. and how to navigate the menus (like how in the original game in the menus the right mouse button was the back button but now it does nothing in the menus). It takes a little bit to break the old habits here but nothing that takes away from the experience. The sound quality is also better. I personally am especially fond of the sound effects of hitting enemies in this game rather than in The Lost Chapters. The blood looks a lot better and splatters more realistically. This game just takes an amazing game and makes it even better. If you like RPGs and/or Fable, you need this game in your life right now.

reviewText:
Fable: Anniversary is the bare minimum for what constitutes as an HD remaster. Sharper textures, better lighting and higher quality sound. The game feels and plays like the original game with the usual loading screens in between sections that you often see in games released back in the day.

It's still the same old Fable at its core, but for some reason the developers made some pretty major changes to the artstyle which make the characters look a bit off.

If you've never played Fable before then this is the game for you. If you, like me, have played the original Fable then this is just an okay remaster that does nothing better than the original. Hell, it does some things worse.

reviewText: Fable was always a treasured memory for me. So when I heard tell of a remake in the works I quickly pre-ordered with all the DLC (like the massive nostalgia-sucker I am).\n\nIf you're expecting all-new quests and gameplay mechanics, look elsewhere. This is a faithful remake with beautifully tacky voice acting and broken economies aplenty. You can do all the things you used to do, fight all the battles you used to fight and listen to people call you chickenchaser in just the same tone they used to (do you chase chickens?")

reviewText:
This is a fantastic remake of a classic game, worthy of anyone's Steam library!

Having only played the original Fable incredibly briefly at a friend's when it was first released, I would still consider myself new to the Fable series.  It has always been one of those games that I've meant to play, but when I first heard about the HD remake, it seemed like the perfect time to actually do so.  First off, the game looks lovely - you only have to compare the visuals from the 2004 release to those in Fable Anniversary to see just how much of an improvement this release offers.  It really brings the game to a standard where you can play it today and it doesn't feel dated, and all without losing the original charm and style of the 2004 game.

As a new player, I've been really enjoying Fable Anniversary - the game feels open enough to give a sense of exploration (the side quests, mini games etc.) but has an interesting and engaging primary quest that keeps you moving forward.  RPG levelling is there and, whilst it might not be as complex as some RPG games these days, I like that I don't have to spend hours in the menus worrying about to which of the tens of attributes I should be allocating my experience!  It's a great adventure game, and one that you can just pick up and enjoy when the mood takes you.  For those who loved the original, I think you'll enjoy rediscovering a game that you played perhaps ten years ago in beautiful HD (or 4K if you're lucky enough to be an early adopter!).  Get it!

reviewText:
What's amazing to me is the amount of people complaining about the game so far for reasons I don't see as legitimate. A legitimate complaint would be why they're charging 34.99 for this, when Fable TLC is only 9.99. An illegitimate complaint would be all the ones I see about the controls.

PC Master Race people, this is a console game that was ported to PC. And there is absolutely no reason they should have to go the extra mile to appease you. The mouse and keyboard were not designed for gaming, a 360 controller was. And as such the keyboard and mouse will ALWAYS be inferior for controls. Unless the game was designed for PC first, which Fable Anniversary was not. Accept that the PC has flaws when it comes to gaming and lower your impossible standards and you'll all enjoy games a lot more. And if you can't handle the fact that your chosen method of playing games is flawed then it is no one's fault but your own. Sorry to burst your little bubbles but PC gaming isn't as perfect as you all like to pretend it is. Especially when the game in question is a port from console.

And I know what you're gonna say. The game should have been designed for PC first" Well it wasn't. And no amount of whining (And that is what you're doing
recommended: because you're not getting everything 100% your way) is going to change that. And you have no right to criticize the developers for putting their game wherever they like. Because it's their game.\n\nSure

reviewText:
I am pretty surprised at all these negative reviews. I really don't see what the big fuss is. Self-entitled kiddos is my guess... Anyone outside of that should be ashamed of themselves for acting like one.

To be honest, I wasn't wanting additional content. I wanted a Fable experience exactly how I recall back in 2004.

On those grounds, Anniversary delivered tremendously.

Fable was a staple of my young adulthood. I beat the thing 20 times before Anniversary released, and after recently purchasing the original TLC for the PC; I really suffered through not having controller support. I ended up using Xpadder, which really sucked due to limited movement.

The added controller support, along with a redesigned UI really addresses the weakpoints of the original game.

The game plays on a completely new engine - Unreal 3, which makes it look incredible. That, coupled with the massive effort to retexture the game really gives the graphics a kick to make it competitive with current releases.

Fable Anniversary also features an audio overhaul, where some parts have been completely redone. No more out of sync voice overs with the character animations!

The majority of people downing this game are ignorant. I've watched people of the community refuse to buy this game for petty reasons like no more silver key glitching with hero saves, or no ability to play as a female. Those are features that were purposely left out because they weren't intended in the original game. These idiots are seriously bashing the game because they fixed bugs from the original...

Overall, if you enjoyed the original game, then you are bound to enjoy Anniversary. As a Fable series enthusiast, and longtime fan of the game; I can definitely say that Anniversary's graphical rebuild does the original game justice. The added controller support and UI overhaul really make the game a much smoother experience on the PC!

It was just like experiencing the original game for the first time again - and in my opinion, you really can't put a price on such a great feeling of nostalgia.

reviewText:
As an RPG lover who has never played a Fable game before (because I only had Playstation), hates playing PC games without a controller so I spent $40 on an Xbox 360 controller and waited 3 weeks for Fable Anniversary's PC release, I am pretty satisfied so far. I recognize that the gameplay could be smoother but it's not as terrible as I expected after reading some reviews by long-time Fable players and gaming experts.  The game is definitely playable, just not super smooth when the hero is running, etc.

It took me a while to figure out the D-pad items/expressions feature, so that lack of instruction gets a thumbs down (I still don't know why my assigned expressions only appear on the D-pad screen icon when I hold Right Trigger and why certain expressions/items get auto-assigned to the regular D-pad screen icon and why I can't change *those*).

I also think there should have been an explanation of the save system at the beginning of the game (or anytime!). I think I'm about to graduate from the Heroes Guild & hopefully I can save anytime after that. Despite the couple annoyances, so far this game has lived up to my expectations. I was hoping for a game like this that would give me future nostalgia, like I have for the old days of playing the Zelda and Final Fantasy series. I'm sure they'll release some patches to improve the framerate but I'm going to continue playing in the meantime; I think it's a cool game and so far, I'm hooked!

reviewText:
Fable Anniversary is a great game!  That said, it is not perfect.  Overall Score: 9/10  My simple review breakdown follows:

Pros:

- Just like you remember the original Fable, except with better graphics.
- One of the greatest RPGs of all time.
- Steam achivements!
- Modding!
- Classic gameplay.

Cons:

- Could have had spent more time redoing character motions and reworked their physics engine to make the game more fluid.

- I hate to be cliche, but classic gameplay.  While it is a pro, it is also a con, because RPGs as well as all other games, have evolved.  I feel like this should have not just had new graphics slapped on.

- No add in of previous Fable advances implemented into the Anniversary Edition?!  This is definitely my biggest pet peeve.  Lionhead introduced us to a whole new realm of customization of our character in Fable 2 and 3, and here we are, back at square one again without the ability to simply have different color hair.  It is my hopes the modding community comes up with a way to fix this.

Overall, great game!  Still worth every penny!  Pick it up!!!

reviewText:
„I like it.“ - This was my original review.

Now there i saw 4 people disliking this review I want to edit it and explain why I like the game.
Fable was my childhood and will be my favourite game forever. This remake of Fable TLC isn't „bad“ or sth like that.
It has better graphics and a new gamemode, which makes the game a lot ♥♥♥♥in' harder, so why are there so many bad reviews you might think.
Most of the negative reviews are very old and were written because of the negative sites of the game, which not really exist anymore.
For example, when the game came out you couldn't use your mouse in the menu - now you can.
The bugs that were complained about are fixed and if you look at the reviews for Xbox360 you can clearly see the game is very good and there are also not as much negative reviews as on PC, which probably is, because they never wanted a cursor based interface.

The only thing that I can really understand as a reason to not review this game is the price.
The game costs 30 bucks and is exactly the same game as the original Fable TLC, but has better graphics and so on.

There you know Fable is my favourite game, it's not really weird that I bought this game on the release day including all DLC's.

I finished the game twice ( once easy mode, once hardcore mode ) and all I can do now is to highly recommend it to anyone, because it's just as great as the original.

reviewText:
Ignore those tipping their fedoras in disgust.

As you'd expect, the game (almost completely) replicates the TLC version of the game with slightly better graphics. Those complaining about lag/frame-rate problems must have some sort of hardware issue (most likely down to their gfx).

There are plenty of reviews on websites such as IGN and YouTube and I'm sure that most people should have an idea what they're actually paying for.

The game has only just been released and modding has yet to achieve one of the main reasons why you have probably purchased this on Steam, rather than a console (that is if you own one).

Whether there will be any new (official) DLC that was not in TLC, is completely a mystery, although one thing is almost certain.  Modders will most likely do so.

If there is one thing I would have to criticise about the game, it would be how easy it is to exploit stores to make money. If I had realised, I would've chosen to play at the Heroic difficulty from the start, rather than do a run-through on the original difficulty.

All-in-all, I've most definitely enjoyed the game so far. It is what it is. I highly recommend using a controller (preferrably a Microsoft Xbox pad) due to some apparant issues there may currently be with using a mouse/keyboard. The port isn't as 'horrendous' as people make it out to be, although saying that, it could have most definitely have been better.

To round-off this review, I'd like to say that if you are curious about buying the game, please do check out reviews/videos online rather than just insta-buying the game and then complaining because 'you thought they'd have improved it more'.

7/10

reviewText:
If you like chasing chickens and enjoy murdering villagers while chasing chickens, you'll love this game.

Short review:Game has flaws. Keyboard and mouse controls work as well as Dark Souls. Graphic options are limited. Sound works. May crash, may not. May also stutter with certain hardware. Unreal game so you can tweak anything.

There are certain flaws that a lot of people pointed out already but it's not that bad, A few people like myself can play this game no problem. I play with a controller so the mouse and keyboard controls don't bother me as much. I bought this game knowing it would be a console port so keep that in mind if you're interested. The game runs smoothly and I've only had it crash every few hours. Hopefully they'll fix that soon but the game saves frequently so it's not enough to cause me much anger.

If you're not a fan of the Anniversary remake you probably won't like this either. The PC port is the 360 version with tacked on mouse and keyboard controls. It feels a lot like Dark Souls. It's rough around the edges but a good game if you play under optimal conditions(using a controller for ex.). Don't expact anything but a console port though and you'll find some enjoyment with this version. Keep in mind there is the original Fable on Steam too if that's what you want but it lacks controller support and that's actually one of the reasons I bought the Anniversary version.

I'd recommend this to anyone who's ok with console ports, if you're not don't buy this game. Also it helps if you're a fan of the Anniversary remake because you know.. if you're not then why are you here?

reviewText:
TL;DR: Get it on sale if you haven't played Fable, or if you want graphical pretties. Keyboard+mouse be dun goofed apparently.

------------------------------------

I was an avid fan of the original Fable and Fable TLC, and the remastered edition doesn't fail to disappoint either.

PROS:
- WIDESCREEN SUPPORT AW YISS. Getting the original to work in widescreen wasn't terribly hard, but it was still hackish and bugged at some critical moments.
- Very nice graphics, they've predominately kept to the core of the graphical characteristics of the Fable series, but it's amazing what a fresh coat of paint (proverbially speaking) can do with a game. Fable has definitely aged well.
- Modding support? I'll be curious to see where this goes, and from what I've read, we may end up having Fable Anniversary coming to the Steam Workshop. Can't imagine it'd be like a Skyrim, though.

CONS:
- No Borderless Window nor scaleable UI. Just a bit of a bummer that I can't have the window maximised since it then causes letterboxing and the like, and considering this is a UE3 game, I'm surprised that we don't even have a borderless window option, since I often alt-tab between windows and would rather have the game appear full screen. I've tried tools to force the borderless window but it doesn't work.
- Some graphical glitches exist where objects won't receive light from nearby light sources, kinda kills immersion a bit but it's not a deal breaker by any means.

ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT:
- Mainly to do with the overall environmental lighting, particularly outdoors, but we could benefit from variations in luminosity, and actually be able to use the lantern at night, right now it just seems pointless to have the lantern since everything is so well lit.
- Some head models can do with some improving too, the child Hero looks like he hasn't slept for a week, and Maze does not look like Maze at all, his characteristic stern look got ruined by an elongated, pudgy, wrinkly baby face with tattoos. |:

I can't speak for the copious amounts of people that have whinged relentlessly about the whole keyboard + mouse thing, I do remember playing Fable TLC with a keyboard and mouse and it was working quite fine, though since then I've been playing games with a 360 controller, and naturally given Fable Anniversary was originally made for the 360, it still feels pretty good to play with. I did try playing with the keyboard+mouse combo, but quickly switched back to the controller. :P

Haven't played through Heroic yet, but that'll be the next step.

reviewText:
Judging by what it was, and not what people wanted it to be, the original Fable the Lost Chapters was excellent, and is one of the most defining games of that generation.

Fable Anniversary retians everything you loved about the original; the humor, the combat and spells, the alignment system, and all those goofy little quests and tasks. But the video quality is updated massively; the models are much better, and the textures really pop as opposed to the original. The draw distance is greatly improved, allowing you to see your enemies much farther away now too, which can be helpful. Also the audio is improved too, but its hardly noticable honestly, given that so much of your attention is usally focused on the game itself.

Achievments now come with it too, giving incentive to finish all those things you never did in the original, or just giving you a reason to finish them all over again. Inluded in those is one for finishing the game on its newly implemented Heroic Mode
date:
which among other things, removes exploits, makes enemies harder and removes resurrection phials, allowing for a much more difficult experience.

The DLC for this game is nothing more than custume packs, which are fun to use, but a little pricy. Still, even these costume packs can add a little more to your experience without feeling out of place from the original, and can also result in hilarious screenshots.

All in all, it's a fantastic way for fans of the original to experience it all over again, and for people who may have skipped it to reconsider and give it a go. It's by no means one of the best RPGs ever made, but its certainly unforgettable.

reviewText:
I don't know what major issues are being experienced but apparently from reading the reviews on this page there is a slue of them. I haven't had any problems with the menu's in game or movement and visually this game casts a shadow over the lost chapters and the xbox original. There was added content but nothing that really matters because this is a HD remake not a reimagining or a retelling, personally I think that it is unfair to demand even MORE of a dev after they've already ported it once and now again. The game includes mods support with the engine editor so any problems to be had are going to be fixed whether we like it or not which is far and beyond what a lot of other games on steam can boast about. I've only just started it up and can't seem to replicate the issues so take this review for what its worth. This game probably won't have a good mouse and keyboard support because it was never intended to be played on a pc without a controller, they aren't even that expensive.

The issue in the end isn't the game its the coddling of the players that is absent that seems to upset people and that doesn't lend to fair judgement of the game.

tl:dr - if you like fable / lost chapters, get it. it looks amazing it has all of the replayability and it has the editor. If your a bargin shopper christmas is coming and we all have wallets that will hurt afterward this should go on sale by then.

reviewText:
Splitting this into 2 parts, Review of the game itself and then the enhancements.
The actual Opinion is right at the bottom if you want to look and if you don't feel like reading through detail.

The game sets you out as a little boy, who has his home town raided by bandits and then saved by a mage known as 'Maze', He then makes you join the Heroes guild, a small guild dedicated to raising people into heroes so they can help Albion, from there it's a very big adventure. Now first off, it's not Elder Scrolls big, there are certain things you can't do but can do, It's between massively open and limited, You can marry, have sex, Buy houses, kill townsfolk (Good luck fist fighting in Bowerstone), Open secret doorways to treasure, buy houses in the towns of people you kill, become incredibly evil or incredibly good (This affects your appearance massively, Evil causes you to lose hair, grow horns, create an evil aura about you and causes your hands and feet to become demonic, while being good causes you to emit a good aura about you, grow white hair and have a Halo above you), but you cannot customise appearance at the start (You can get a haircut, get a beard, tattoo's, become fat by eating too much, becoming good/evil, old, Muscly and scarred), you cannot create your own adventure, your name is always 'Hero' and titles you can buy, Not immersive that highly and do all that creating weapons (There is more but I didn't want to keep this going forever).

Now is this like Skyrim? Certainly not, the only reason I compared them with openess because everyone recognises Skyrim as the big RPG. It's a medium sized fantasy RPG action game, most people would think that because it's a fantasy RPG action game, it's similar to Skyrim, however it has it's own unique style, instead of being an entire fantasy world populated with elves, orcs and all that, It's basically medieval britian with magic and monsters, Does this ruin the game? No, not at all, for the time it was a incredibly refreshing change from Orcs and Elf fantasies (Still is).

The combat for this game is quite basic, You have heavy weapons, light weapons, Bows/Crossbows and magic, Basic combat stuff like Swing, Block and a heavy attack, Heavy Weapons are incredibly sluggish to use (Don't expect to use them right away until your Physique is high enough) while light weapons are quick (No Dual wielding), Bows can be used to engage fights from a distance at first so they come to you, however headshotting an enemy will do high damage and can instantly kill them if strong enough and magic is something you can use to get around enemies, slow time, do deadly AoE attacks or summon/turn enemies against them. Leveling in this game is hugely different, in fact, leveling doesn't exist, you get EXP drops from enemies you kill or quests you complete, and you spend them at the guild to upgrade your magic, your skills (Speed, accuracy and guile) or upgrade your power (Health, Physique and Strength), killing enemies without getting hit will give huge boosts to EXP drops so make sure to be quick on your feet.


Now for Actual opinion, The game is quite a great game, despite the series never living up to it's expectations, it's still a great game and the beginning of a great adventure, the story does better than most RPGs and keeps you invested to the end at least, the world is quite a lovely place, the gameplay is basic but good enough to get through the game, the music is absolutely gorgeus and the setting is amazing. Easy 9/10 for me

Now is the graphical enhancement worth it?
It looks very beautiful compared to the old game, no edges seen, but it isn't exactly todays standards but still nice and it's definitely as I remember it, the only issue I had with this was the menus, some of the layouts weren't that great but the UI is definitely improved, The only issue I have with this compared to the old game was nagivating through the menus, it was a bit of a chore to do, but they seem like they will be fixing that eventually and they are planing to allow more mod making soon (Currently it's just small things).

So I do think this game is worth it if you are an RPG fan, it does it's job of entertaining you from start to finish and does contain british humour every once and a while

reviewText:
*IMPORTANT NOTICE MUST READ!*
Please, do not listen to the lists of negative reviews!
The heavy hitting issues have been resolved and the minor ones are being worked on, and for the product it's self...

Fable is a very unique game and remains fun to this day (The original was released in 2004) This game is truly a landmark in the RPG genre, the mechanics and gameplay remains untouched by it's sequels despite being outdated per se I would reccomend this game to anyone.
On to the new stuff, the improvments to the Graphics and Lighting are indeed incredible! This is the same great game that you should have played, it found small non-game breaking elements to add in; such as Fable II - III game pad layout designs some new gear (via DLC)But more importantly a new addition is mod support! If you are not familier with the term, the simple explination is more mods. Tools like this make it very easy for modders to create new models etc!

If you are wondering why I did not mention the story, I think the story is ment to unfold as if it where new as the main goal to this game is to choose your path. (Dont worry, not at all complicated like Dead Rising etc.)

10/10 - One of the greatest games of all time.

reviewText:
Fable Anniversary is a great remake of an amazing classic.

I also feel the huge ammount of complaints some people have been having with this game to be very negligable.

Negligable Complaints:
Art style, A lot of people were expecting a more realistic art style for the game instead of a slight cartoony/fantasy look. I feel the art style the devs used works VERY well with the game, and increases the ammount of charm the Fable games give, so far everything I have seen looks asthetically pleasing.

Not RPG enough, If you have never played a Fable game, you MUST realize before playing that this game is NOTHING like an Elder scrolls, Dark souls, or Witcher game. Fable is VERY casual in comparison, and doesn't take itself nearly as seriously. Despite there also being a harder difficulty to choose from than normal, the game is still very much casual.

Real Complaints:

The AI, The AI of a lot of the NPC's in this game is very clunky, and a bit buggy especially when trying to get people to follow you.

Bad cut scenes, During a lot of minor dialogue cut scenes, everything in the background seems to stop moving except for you, and the NPC you;re talikng to. This can lead to some very distracting, or awkward backgrounds with NPC's just frozen in the middle of an activity. Also the audio during chapter progression cutscenes is very low quality, and even crackles at times like the original game.

The $35 asking price, $35 dollars is just way to much for ecentially upgraded visuals, and audio especially when the original, and its Lost Chapters DLC are available on Steam as well.

Over all though this game is extremely fun and very replayable
The Achievments are also a nice bonus, especially since most of them leave you with two different methods to unlock it, so the path / play style you choose won't impact if you can earn the achievment or not.

reviewText: I am loving the remastering of a favourite game from my past, but there is a major bug still in the works (either connectivity to the server or some overlooked animation problem)  regardless, the game lags to high hell mid combat then regains it's composure just long enough to allow you the gripping visual of your own death. reviewText:
Since I wrote my original review, there have been patches implimented into Fable Anniversary Edition! The game comes off as more stable, but still has rendering issues in the Arena when it comes to the cut-scenes with the hero, audience, Jack of Blades, and Lady Grey scenes. I also am confused by the system used to assign keys for the D-Pad. I assign them, but cannot seem to use them. Those are my only urks at this moment.

Aside from the urks of rendering issues with certain points of the game, Fable feels like the original. The game-play is very smooth with the XBox 360 controller and the Fable 2-3 controls (unless you are assigning to your D pad, as mentioned before). The game matains the feeling I had with the Original Fable and Lost Chapters versions of the games and gives you a nostolgic feel when you play it.

If you are a big Fable fan, and can get past the issues of rendering delays, and the D-Pad issues, then I would reccomend the game! Despite the flaws, it is still a lot of fun and a great trip down memory lane for those who once played it on the Xbox. There is much the world of Albion has to offer you, once more!

If you cannot stand those problems I listed, I suggest waiting for more patches or look into getting Fable: Lost Chapters instead (You cannot play that version of Fable with a gamepad unless you get a seperate program that allows it. It is a strictly a Keyboard and mouse version of the game). If you are still on the fence, the best I can tell you is to wait for the game to go on sale and take a chance on it.

As for the DLC, you do not need it. The DLC only gives you the ability to BUY the items in game, and they items are insanely expensive or hard to find. I was hoping we got the items off the bat once you became an adult, but nope. Unless it goes down to super cheap, I suggest you save your money and play the game as is.

reviewText:
This is my first in depth review of a Game here on Steam.

I'll divide my review into the typical; Good, Bad, And Ugly.
I hope you find my review helpful in more way that one.

Good: Graphics overhaul;
The graphics were improved drastically since the release of TLC. Lighting was improved, as well as minor details such as foliage, bumpmapping on armour and weapons. The character models recieved smoother animations, along with better voice recognition so the character mouths don't look so rigid or twitchy.  The lighting and shadows were also improved to give the overall look of the game a much greater atomosphere.

Sound;
If you notice one thing like I have, it's that most, if not all of the original sounds, from combat, ambient sounds, to the sound track, sound exactly the same as they did in the original and TLC. I'm glad they decided to go this route as to keep a sense of nostalgia. No use redoing what you already had done, right? Now don't get me wrong, a lot of the voice acting in the Original Fable along with TLC was attrocious by any means. They could have gone out and tried to rerecord all of the voice acting, but it's been several years since the original voice actors recorded. Also, it wouldn't be much of an Anniversary" Edition with different vocals. I'm glad they decided to keep all of the original voices

Now for the Bad.

reviewText:
Heroes, your satisfaction energy is low. What's that?

That's what I'm seeing with these reviews... Damn people can't you get enough? I must say, the remastered version is superb!
I've played a lot of the Fable TLC, back in the day, and I loved it. So, I had to buy the HD remake, even when I am low on money, just for the nostalgia, and for supporting Lionhead because lately they don't really trust PC gamers, so I wanted to help. And when I started to play I found out that the game is actually a really good fun. The combat the same, the silly dialoge and voice acting, but the graphics are more up to date(I must say, the old graphics made it a bit hard to love, but that's just me).
Sure, the game doesn't really looks like on the pictures here on steam, but it's still really nice and I like it, even a bit more the original.
And sure, there are some keyboard problems, but It's good to see they are updating it now to make sure everything is just as nice as it could be.
So stop being so judgey all of sure. I know you want to get the max out of the money you put on the game, but they are trying, and it's still a dated game, but now with dated models, graphics, and audio.

Don't drink from the pool of hatred, bro

reviewText:
I'm glad the game was made into HD. I am  extremely interested in the history inside this fantasy setting, although I hypothesise that a next installment might cover this. Heroic mode, however, was mostly a rough start; acquiring a certain objective through a extreme amount of spawned enemies towards the ##spoiler boss was harder than that boss himself. In particular, the slow time spell is extremely powerful.

After gaining competence in combat, I accumulated so many health potions that the shop exploit, where selling/buying/selling/cycles generate 2-3k gold per cycle, was accessible even in fable anniversary heroic.

I can offer no alternatives for this; but I did greatly enjoy my first playthrough [heroic, good, archer] and started on a second [evil mage].
